. I was not able to reproduce the issue on the clean installation. However, I was able to track down the source of the problem on my working configuration. It is the contents of Folder History. After cleaning it ConEmu stopped crashing. It is yet not clear what caused it to crash: a particular entry or history size by itself. History.FolderHistory.Count setting had the default value of 1000.
. I figured out what causes ConEmu to crash. It is the length of Folder History items. For example, I have the width of the console configured to 178 characters. ConEmu crashes when there is an item of 170 characters or more. Folder History dialog is able to accommodate up to 169 characters (it expands its width). After the dialog takes up all the width, Far Manager's behavior is to trim too long items using the » character. It seems that ConEmu cannot handle this.
. I made a minimal history.db which can be used to reproduce the issue. The key is presence of a long entry that needs to be truncated (169 characters or more) while the total number of entries exceeds 35. Then ConEmu crashes upon opening Folder History. It stops crashing once at least one entry is removed or the long one made shorter.
Please note that the console size is 178 by 48. Folder History looks like this (edge case before it starts crashing):

. The issue disappeared starting with the version 170316. I can only assume there were changes in that version related to the cause of crashing..

miniksa:
Hey @Maximus5,
@bitcrazed, our PM, found this SetWindowPos issue being discussed on Twitter the other day and filed it as a bug in my system. I followed up with the team responsible for rendering window placement and got the following answers to some of your questions:
- Is it a confirmed bug? Is it a feature?
  It's somewhat in the middle. I asked the team responsible for the window framing and they said they consider the invisible frame to be By Design. I personally believe by some technicality, the frame still exists but is just invisible for theming/styling reasons, so they don't consider it a bug exactly. 
- Is there any workaround to put the window at the edge of the monitor working area?
  This is where I got you an answer. :) The team says that you can use the DwmGetWindowAttribute function (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa969515(v=vs.85).aspx) with the parameter DWMWA_EXTENDED_FRAME_BOUNDS to find the "visual rect" of the window as known to the window manager. A little calculation between that RECT and the one you already have for your window will let you know how many invisible pixels there are outside your bounds and let you compensate accordingly for the invisible border.
I hope that helps you out!
--Michael

I also don't know what in the system turns that metric on or off.
From what I know about the console from Win 8.1 to today, the console always did its conversions and width calculations based on code page. It's just that prior to recently, it used to prohibit changing into a CJK codepage unless your system's non-Unicode region was set to a CJK language (Control Panel-->Region-->Administrative-->Language for non-Unicode programs). I've been trying to remove that restriction to allow anyone to swap into any codepage no matter their "non-Unicode region" because in today's editions of Windows (as opposed to the CJK-specific ones of the 1990s), you can add just about any language pack and IME and font to any language edition of Windows, so the "non-Unicode" region doesn't really matter like it used to several decades ago.
My plan is:
- Go back into the DBCS tests and expand them significantly across these APIs against the v1 console (legacy) since everything was "fine" before we mucked around with it.
- Correct anything in v2 that is no longer compliant with the DBCS tests (including all the APIs you listed above).
- Get that set of fixes and tests shipping up toward the insiders build.
- Get you some documentation/research on how all this is supposed to work (including that SM_DBCSENABLED flag in the console context) and potentially get that sort of information published to MSDN.. So I've got through 1, 2, and 3 in MSFT: 10187355 which is checked in and will start shipping up to Insiders builds. Probably be there in a few weeks. I've basically restored the console's behavior to the same as what it was for the legacy console. If it works against the console with the legacy box checked, it will work again against the updated one once the Insider build updates.

In comparison on my 15014 system, calling uf on the same function gives me 50+ assembly instructions, not 3. And it doesn't start with add byte ptr[rax], al, it starts with the more sensible retrieval of the stack variable with mov instructions to retrieve the single TRUE/FALSE parameter to this function.
0:007> uf advapi32!PerflibciSetObjectsValidityState
ADVAPI32!PerflibciSetObjectsValidityState:
 2194 00007fff`84ba6d18 488b0424        mov     rax,qword ptr [rsp]
 2194 00007fff`84ba6d1c 6448890424      mov     qword ptr fs:[rsp],rax
 2194 00007fff`84ba6d21 53              push    rbx
 2194 00007fff`84ba6d22 4883ec20        sub     rsp,20h
 2194 00007fff`84ba6d26 8ad9            mov     bl,cl
.... (more lines, I clipped them out) ....
Additionally, the exception itself...
0:006> .ecxr
rax=0000000001d26bee rbx=0000000000000000 rcx=0000000000000000
rdx=00007ff93d9e180c rsi=0000000000000000 rdi=0000000000001000
rip=00007ff93d9d6d18 rsp=0000003ffb1fe168 rbp=0000003ffb1fe1d0
 r8=0000003ffb1fe0c8  r9=0000003ffb1fe1d0 r10=0000000000000000
r11=0000003ffb1fe168 r12=0000000000000063 r13=0000000000000000
r14=0000000000000000 r15=0000000000000000
iopl=0         nv up ei pl zr na po nc
cs=0033  ss=002b  ds=002b  es=002b  fs=0053  gs=002b             efl=00010246
advapi32!PerflibciSetObjectsValidityState:
00007ff9`3d9d6d18 0000            add     byte ptr [rax],al ds:00000000`01d26bee=??
The exception is a write access error to the memory at 1d26bee. But that's not where the heaps are with !heap and it's not inside any library or valid address space with !address. So if it's trying to write to invalid memory for no particularly good reason, that's why we hit an access violation. 
But reading the source code for this function... there is no write operation that should be occurring immediately on entry to PerflibciSetObjectsValidityState. It should have grabbed its parameters off the stack, checked that the lock variable was not null (read access), and then jumped immediately to kernel32!WaitForSingleObject on the lock value it just checked. 
So I further suspect something has tampered with advapi32.dll.
BitDefender could be a good suspect. AntiVirus applications commonly place hooks inside system DLLs and detour them. Perhaps this was a bad detouring of advapi32 or a hook/detour that can't compensate for some compiler/linker update that adjusted the layout of advapi32.dll.
So as of now, I don't really have anything to file unfortunately as it doesn't look like a race condition at all to me. It looks like some other piece of software on @asser-dk's system is tampering with system DLLs and that's not something we support. . OK, I got some time to look at this and figured a few things out.


The issue where when you resize the ConEmu window, the bash command line ends up wrapping early or no longer being aligned with the window frame. This appears to be the primary issue described above.


This manifested itself mainly as the Bash input line redrawing on top of itself. It would make it some/most of the way across the window, then the cursor would carriage return onto the beginning of the same line and start drawing on top of itself.

This one had no real work around other than resizing the window back to the size it originally was, so I made a fix for it.
It turned out that we weren't sending enough messages to the WSL subsystem to let it know that the window and buffer were being updated and it needed to relay that information into the WSL environment. That means you could get into a scenario where Bash inside WSL environment was told that the buffer changed, but not that the window changed (or vice versa) and it would wrap early or late and emit the wrong VT sequences for what it was trying to do.

This fix should be coming to Insiders builds in the next few weeks and has been encompassed in the 12092729 bug I generated above for investigation.


The issue where when you have a Bash input line full of stuff, you resize the window with Word Wrap/Reflow resize on (in the "real console") and suddenly the Bash line is reprinted above/below where you expect it, sometimes leaving extraneous characters behind.

This one seems to be because Bash doesn't expect the terminal to reflow text in the way that we do. It repaints its entire prompt line and everything you wrote on it after every change/modification. If the reflow moved it to another line because there was space, it can break some of Bash's assumptions and it will then repaint strangely and differently.
The workaround to this one is to just clear the screen after reflowing or disabling reflowing in the real console. Everything should be fine from there on out. 
One of my co-workers has a long term task filed to investigate if we can make Bash and other utilities like this play nicer with the Word Wrap/Reflow resize, but that's not a simple bug fix like part 1 above (we never considered that in our original design, so we'll have to go do some experiments and potentially go back to the drawing board.)

Thanks for your patience with this and thank you for reporting this issue!
--Michael. Hi Maximus,
There's not currently a way to programmatically adjust the reflowing setting. You can adjust it with the LineWrap REG_DWORD key under HKCU console before starting a console session (for those that load from the registry), or you can UI automate it off the property sheet... but there's no API or anything nice like that right now. :( 
We have some people trying to figure out a comprehensive update to our settings story and exposing the difficult-to-set-settings is one of the things included in it, but I have no promises on timeline.
Sorry it's so obtuse. You might have to resort to a creative workaround in the meantime. 
Thanks,
--Michael

. No, there is no way to trigger a paste event from the outside in a 100% reliable manner. 
We've been investing effort into letting wrappers/host applications use ConPTY to become the hosting environment instead of further building out the console client API. If you use ConPTY to host things, then you event and handle the paste in whatever manner you choose and inject the results into the PTY input stream.
Also, there's no secret WM for paste. We just process Ctrl+V under certain conditions as a paste, but only when it's coming down our window procedure, not via the input queue API.
There actually is a WM_PASTE message, but we're not using it at this moment.
Finally, if whatever shell you are using at the end of the pipeline decides it wants to treat the tab character as an auto-complete, then it will. In this case, it might be CMD.exe is buggy. But there's virtually no chance of fixing CMD.exe given that every time we change anything "minor," it turns out to break half of the world.. leycec:
Let's do this.
An Ideological Divide
In the early 2000's, an ideological spectrum referred to by the two antipoles "deletionism" and "inclusionism" erupted on Wikipedia. Ironically, this bitter feud received sufficient media attention to be included in Wikipedia:

"Deletionists" are proponents of selective coverage and removal of articles seen as unnecessary or highly substandard... Deletionists favor objectivity and conformity, holding that "Wikipedia is not Google," a "junkyard," or "a dumping ground for facts." They argue that the interest of enough people is a necessary condition for article quality, and articles about trivial subjects damage the credibility and future success of Wikipedia. They advocate the establishment and enforcement of specific standards and policies as a form of jurisprudence.
"Inclusionists" are proponents of broad retention, including retention of "harmless" articles and articles otherwise deemed substandard to allow for future improvement... Inclusionists may argue that the interest of a few is a sufficient condition for the existence of an article, since such articles are harmless and there is no restriction on space in Wikipedia. Favoring the idiosyncratic and subjective, an inclusionist slogan is "Wikipedia is not paper."

Observe the use of such words as "conformity," "enforcement," and "jurisprudence" in describing deletionists. But what sort of human might be attracted to words like that?
The Deletionists Have Won
Yes, that sort.
To paint with an admittedly wide brush, deletionists are both fundamentalist and conservative (in every categorical sense of those adjectives); inclusionists are not. Since spoken language is inherently subjective, however, there exists no unbiased means of quantifying which articles satisfy the deletionists' necessary condition of "...the interest of enough people" and which do not.
Given that, deletionism is inherently biased towards maintenance of status quo topics – which, in my concerned opinion, is antithetical to our continued accumulation of knowledge as a species. Unfortunately, at least with respect to open-source software, the deletionists have won.
The War on Open-Source
I can hardly count the number of open-source projects with Wikipedia pages that either were successfully deleted or are currently flagged for deletion. The reason why is simple: Wikipedia's notability requirements for software articles are sufficiently draconian that effectively no open-source software meets them. These requirements can be synopsized by the following catechism:
If Google books, Google news, and Google scholar yield no hits for your project, your article will be deleted.
Then let us query:
1. Is ConEmu sufficiently complex to require the publication of for-profit dead-tree books disseminating its use?
   - No, of course not.
2. Is ConEmu sufficiently mainstream to incentivize the scrutiny of for-profit mass media television or newspaper outlets?
   - No, of course not.
3. Is ConEmu sufficiently academic to warrant the publication of for-profit peer-reviewed papers formalizing its theory?
   - No, of course not. (Yes, Elsevier and related academic publishers are highly profitable. Let us ponder the ethicality of privatizing a common good payed for purely by taxpayer dollars. But I digress.)
Of course, few to no open-source projects ever have or will meet such ludicrous eligibility requirements.
The size of your userbase is irrelevant. The number of daily downloads, frontpage hits, blog posts, or tech articles vis-à-vis your project is irrelevant. All that matters to the garden-variety Wikipedian is: "Do members of the for-profit intelligentsia profit from and therefore formally discuss your work in a publicly monetized setting?"
If not, you're going to have a hard time. Hence, open-source software has a hard time. Hence, Wikipedia has become effectively castrated with respect to open-source software.
On the bright side, nature abhors a vacuum. By ceding all of the informational territory on open-source software to the vacuum of /dev/null, Wikipedia has made it trivial for competitors with less rigidly doctrinaire policies to capture their readership. (Let us pray to Stallman this happens soon.) 
tl;dr
Due to a dysfunctional culture of fundamentalist zealotry, Wikipedia fails with respect to open-source software. There's little to nothing we can do about that. Best of luck, Maximus5 and cohort.

I digged into the problem, because mintty (from Git for Windows) does not come with tabs and vertical/horizontal split, and since two weeks, I'm forcing myself/forced to use it at work because whenever I do something on my tabs, then want to use less, I've got a crash.
Based on the link provided by @Maximus5, I wrote a sample script which failed on my installation, this may be a good help to change the value of Long console output (see screenshot below) to an acceptable value:
echo whatever > whatever.txt
for i in {1..4600}; do echo $i; done
less whatever.txt
echo 1
The last line will crash, because it seems to be the limit for Cygwin. The echo 1 is optional, it just to be sure that ConEmu will execute the less command.
I noticed that changing the TERM from cygwin to xterm "fix" the issue: less is unusable (it does not help ncurses to work), but it does not crash. It is worst on vim: arrows are no longer recognized, the term is not cleared (there are junk from ls for instance), ... 
Also, in my understanding of cygwin' code, the error is not related to the buffer height (that would also explain when changing TERM affect the outcome of less crashing); cygwin split cmalloc memory in buckets (40) and the size we want simply outbound that block size (max is 6291456/12582912 if I read this comment here). 
Whatever that size is, or where it come, is another question.

This is a whole different setup from previous git for Windows; might be worth updating that StackOverflow answer.

This is a convenience feature. If you run a process and it quits before 10 seconds are up, ConEmum keeps the tab open until you press a key. That ensures if you run some program that ends quickly, you can still see the messages it produces. You can change this to be always/never/10 seconds only in the settings.
Are you referring to Settings > Integration > Default Term > Confirm close (Press Enter or Esc to close console): [Automatic/Always/Never] ?. Yes, of course :). Thanks Maximus5. However, the instructions you provide are somewhat involved. Hence, I think that my original request - viz., 'provide easy way to give a more fully Linux-like prompt' (stress added) - stands.. ### Solution
In Properties, I've checked Compatibility mode on Windows 8, and the conemu exit gracefully 

. I expected this to seem like an odd suggestion. Hopefully I can explain why I bothered to recommend it. It could be a fair bit of work, but there is functionality that people are wanting but that no extant program has. My understanding of how ConEmu runs the shells it supports makes it the closest to implementing what is necessary.


SSH - I can run an SSH client inside of ConEmu, but if I use it to connect to a Windows SSH server I can't use it with most Windows programs. Per the bug I linked there are parts of the OS that get in the way. SSH client connections can not create terminal services sessions without lots of additions to OpenSSH.


RDP - I do not mean that ConEmu should somehow interact with the full remote desktop. That would not make much sense. It would be my hope to expose a shell started on a remote session via ConEmu.


I can think of a few ways to do what I have suggested. Some of them involve using features of RDP, but some are more basic, like starting some kind of server in the new session to pipe back the shell interface.
If you don't want to do this that is fine, but I thought to suggest it as this is the only project I have seen that manages to successfully do invasive process hooks for a real usecase, and that may be necessary expertise.

ferenczy:

But you're rendering the console window yourself, aren't you? Aren't you able to change scrollbar's behavior?
. I agree with that buffer can be "dirty" under a cursor position, I was talking about position of the last content in the buffer, not about cursor position, from the very first post. So it's not about a restriction, it's about proper UX (User eXperience) - nobody is interested to scrolling to an empty buffer.
For example MinTTY (Cygwin's default terminal emulator) or ConsoleZ works exactly as I described. It's incomparably more user friendly.
. It fails in MinTTY mainly because it's not running under Windows console (GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo failed, not a console?).
Dirty is simply a line in a buffer, into which something was written (we can say except of white space characters). If something writes into previously empty buffer to the line 9997, than that line becomes the last line (or line with the highest number) of "buffer content".
I don't understand, why it should be so hard to implement - each line of buffer would have a dirty flag. Scrollbar's effective area then would be from the line 0 to the last line with a dirty flag set to true. That's all. You can even forget about dirty flag for each line and have just one variable, which holds the line with the highest number into which something was written.

Work work work

shawwn:
Chiming in from the future: I too tried setting it to a value like 9999999, which got truncated to 9999, which made me WTF that ConEmu won't go above 9999 lines.
I'm a serious dev doing serious dev work and serious devs need infinite scrollback. 32766 is kind of limiting. Would you accept a PR to increase the max size beyond 32766?. I like a challenge.. See #1604.. Related to #393. The patch is working. I quickly realized it was impossible to create buffers larger than 32k. Instead, I improved the UI, and default to maximum size instead of 9999.. This change is necessary. When the user enters 222222 or 111111, ConEmu now switches to 32766.
If we revert this, users will get confused when they try to enter 222222.  The user’s goal is to max out the value. Without this change, 222,222 will max out at 22,222, not 32,766 as expected.
Same for 111111. . Hi, see my reply at https://github.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/pull/1604#issuecomment-397253345
This can't be rolled back without breaking the UI when the user enters 222222 or 111111. Users do that when they want to set the output height to maximum value (which is 32766 in this case)..

2. Start a GitBash console (e.g. "%ConEmuDir%\..\Git\git-cmd.exe" --no-cd --command=usr/bin/bash.exe -l -i)
3. run npm install command in a project with a large number of dependencies (you can find a open source project on GitHub - pick this one if you want: https://github.com/erikras/react-redux-universal-hot-example)
4. while the process is running, try to stop it using Ctr+C keyboard shortcut
Expected result:
- process stops and you can use the console to do other stuff
Actual result:
- process stops but after a long delay and the current console is not usable

ConEmu is an amazing piece of software on Windows. The paramount, for me, is still iTerm on a Mac, the UX is quite unmatched.. Like @Rabbit52 said, MSYS2_PATH_TYPE=inherit is the key. I prefer not to change the shipped msys2_shell.cmd so here are my two ConEmu tasks for MSYS2:
Bash::Msys2-64
(This is one of the preinstalled tasks, unmodified)

set CHERE_INVOKING=1 & set "PATH=%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\usr\bin;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-msys2-64.exe -new_console:p %ConEmuDrive%\msys64\usr\bin\bash.exe --login -i -new_console:C:"%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\msys2.ico"

Bash::mingw64

set CHERE_INVOKING=1 & set MSYSTEM=MINGW64 & set MSYS2_PATH_TYPE=inherit & set "PATH=%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\mingw64\bin;%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\usr\bin;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-msys2-64.exe -new_console:p %ConEmuDrive%\msys64\usr\bin\bash.exe --login -i -new_console:C:"%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\msys2.ico"

With this setup, I keep the default limited PATH for the msys shell while I use the full path for the mingw64 shell. Here is some great info on the two shells and how PATH is treated.. Yes. ConEmu-Maximus5 is a Windows console emulator with tabs, which represents multiple consoles and simple GUI applications as one customizable GUI window with various features.

josh-egan-ps:
So I discovered that the root cause is that if any command window is running, such as cmd, bash, or anything else, that the drives aren't updated until they are all closed. This includes background processes. By searching through the running processes and killing all shell instances, then the path is correctly loaded the next time a shell is started, whether through ConEmu or stand alone.
So this is not an issue with ConEmu, but I thought I'd share my findings in case anyone else stumbles across this.
.

strrchr:
I think explorer.exe update environment variables of itself from the following registry entries on WM_SETTINGCHANGE:
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment
Then explorer.exe start a new process, the new process inherit the new environment variables.
ConEmu may provide an option to take this behavior.
For simplicity, we can ignore the exported changes from console up to ConEmu process.
Otherwise, there should be an algorithm to calculate the delta from ConEmu startup environment variables to system environemnt variables. And on WM_SETTINGCHANGE, load new system environemnt variables and apply the delta.

norswap:
@Maximus5 
The problem is that the behaviour is inconsistent when consoles are set up to open in new tabs.
(And I think this is what @sferencik is really trying to say.)

The first time I launch a console, ConEmu launches and inherits the explorer's environment.
The second time I launch it, assuming a ConEmu window is open, I get a new tab in that window, which inherits the ConEmu window's environment (so any intermediate changes to the explorer environment are not picked up).

In one case I inherit the explorer's environment, in the other I do not. Confusing, and bad.
If you set up ConEmu to open new windows instead of new tabs, you don't have that problem. Another inconsistency!
I don't really care about processing WM_SETTINGCHANGE or not. The environment of the ConEmu window doesn't preoccupy me*. It's the console I launched that really needs to inherit the explorer's environment
* Although I'm all in favor of https://github.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/issues/987 -- but at least the current behaviour has a certain logic to it.
. The ability to run a script when opening a new tab would indeed be of tremendous help. I don't remember very well (it's been more than 18 months) but I tried to investigate that and I don't think it is possible in ConEmu. The ability to run a script whenever a console is opened (no matter the method) would also help. I someone wants to investigate.... Indeed, I thought I had tested that already, but apparently not. I set my init script up to call a script that resets the PATH variable (one could use the ResetEnv.cmd script @Koriit linked above) and it works fine :+1: .

gregorko:
@norswap
It should be possible to run a script when opening a new tab. There is also a default script ConEmu adds to CMD tabs.
If you look into Settings -> Startup -> Tasks and click on one of the CMD tasks you should see its command in a text field. Usually it should start with cmd.exe. What you see after the /k option is a script that is run when the tab is opened. For example I use this:
cmd.exe /k "%ConEmuBaseDir%\CmdInit.cmd" -git C:\Development\Tools\ConEmuCmdInit.cmd''
%ConEmuBaseDir%\CmdInit.cmd is the ConEmu default script that does adjustments to the prompt and adds Git information if the -git option is specified. Followed by my own ConEmuCmdInit.cmd script that does initialization of my development environment..

Checking:
1) Take Visual Studio version 10+ (9 won't do yet). I'm trying on 12 and 14.
2) Place the .nuget into some folder.
3) Go to VS | Tools | Options | Nuget Package Manager | Package Sources. Add your folder as another source.
4) Create a new C# project (say, Class Library, does not matter here).
5) In Solution Explorer, on the References node under the project, choose Context Menu | Manage Nuget Packages.
6) Here UI depends on VS (nuget extension) version. Generally, you should choose "browse" / "online" section of that UI for installing new ones, select your new nuget source among the sources, and install the package.
7) It should add a line to packages.config file, and an <Import /> element to .csproj pointing to the .Targets file from the nuget package.
8) When you rebuild the project, the ConEmu files from the package should get copied to the outdir of the project.
For now, that's the most useful outcome of the package: if you're building some C# stuff with ConEmu, that's how you get its binaries delivered (same on your machine or whoever takes the project from source control and hits "Restore Packages" in VS, or they can be restored on build). Once it gets uploaded to nuget.org, you'd just have it listed in the packages dialog out of the box.

. I was able to solve this using ShellLinkPlus. I'll keep a copy around in case the link goes offline.
1. Create a shortcut to ConEmu.exe (by dragging the file to the desktop while pressing Ctrl and Shift)
2. Open the shortcut to ConEmu.exe with ShellLinkPlus and copied the AppUserModelID of Maximus5.ConEmu.65e5e8abd9dc7c7e7764bf48b6084339
3. Close ShellLinkPlus
4. Create a custom shortcut with C:\Tools\ConEmu\ConEmu.exe /loadcfgfile "C:\Tools\ConEmu\ConEmu-%COMPUTERNAME%-detached.xml" pinned to the Task Bar (e.g. drag and edit properties)
5. Open the custom shortcut with ShellLinkPlus
6. Paste the copied AppUserModelID into the custom shortcut
7. Click "Create Shortcut"
8. Bliss ;-)

mwtrigg:
PowerShell already has very capable native transcript capabilities; I can think of three methods to achieve what you seek without taxing ConEmu.
These can be enabled by 1. adding a Start-Transcript to your profile, 2. enabling same via a local or domain GPO (COMPUTER|USER(Policies)Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Windows PowerShell -> Turn on PowerShell Transcription), or 3. editing a registry key (HKLM\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\Transcription -> EnableTranscripting = 1).

When user create new console tab in ConEmu there is two tabs with default names: "<1> cmd", "<2> cmd". . First, thanks a lot for reading, for trying TeraTerm (I'm impressed that you fact-checked).
Sorry If I'm insisting but yes, after using "Reset Terminal" screen is completely blank, and yes, the prompt is not displayed anymore. But know what ? Just by pressing a single "enter" the prompt is displayed again.
Example cases :
1. When for example inspecting a real-time log (tail -f), if I have already millions of scrolled lines, being able to visually "clear" everything without stopping the current command is invaluable !
2. When developping an app in read-modify-execute mode, how many times did I accidentally scrolled too far and mistook former run output with the last output ? Being able to clear the terminal completely prevents such pains.
Without such a feature, the only way to clearly separate batches of console output is by making enough «visual space» by, for ex., your aforementioned «ctrl+L» or by keeping "enter" pressed for a long time. Both methodes are not very effective at preventing "lost in scroll history" situations :-( 
As a fellow developper, I hope the examples I give will ring some bells.
Btw this feature is so useful that it's also available in default Terminal app of standard Ubuntu :

Convenientely mapped to F1 : so perfect !
Obviously, using this command while in a curses-heavy interactive shell application like vim is a bad idea. But it's only a rare use case !

. So here's a more concrete proposal: have tab templates support a new %* token for the Selected tab, which would translate to ⬤ in the tab name. See it here in action:

```diff
From a19bb4b8fb0185c6c6bf5cf50c5273d9a39b9ee7 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Christian Boos cboos@bct-technology.com
Date: Sat, 3 Dec 2016 23:49:53 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] gh-552: Add %* format in tab templates for selected indicator

src/ConEmu/ConEmu.rc         | 2 +-
 src/ConEmu/TabBar.cpp        | 6 ++++++
 src/ConEmuCD/ConsoleMain.cpp | 2 +-
 3 files changed, 8 insertions(+), 2 deletions(-)
diff --git a/src/ConEmu/ConEmu.rc b/src/ConEmu/ConEmu.rc
index 5f1f4a2..e9ec0f6 100644
--- a/src/ConEmu/ConEmu.rc
+++ b/src/ConEmu/ConEmu.rc
@@ -1007,7 +1007,7 @@ BEGIN
     RTEXT           "Charset:",stTabFontCharset,225,79,90,8
     COMBOBOX        tTabFontCharset,319,77,54,67,CBS_DROPDOWNLIST | CBS_AUTOHSCROLL | WS_VSCROLL | WS_TABSTOP
     EDITTEXT        tTabConsole,58,130,106,12,ES_AUTOHSCROLL
-    LTEXT           "%s - Title, %c - Console #, %n - Active process name, %p - PID,\n%a - ‘Admin’, %d - current shell directory, %f - folder, %% - %",stTabTemplateDescr,57,110,314,16
+    LTEXT           "%s - Title, %c - Console #, %n - Active process name, %p - PID, % - Selected tab\n%a - ‘Admin’, %d - current shell directory, %f - folder, %% - %",stTabTemplateDescr,57,110,314,16
     RTEXT           "Maximum tab width (in chars):",stTabLenMax,8,168,123,8
     EDITTEXT        tTabLenMax,135,166,40,12,ES_AUTOHSCROLL
     EDITTEXT        tAdminSuffix,301,189,72,12,ES_AUTOHSCROLL

ChasonDeshotel:
Looks like Microsoft fixed this March 20th. Limited to Insider builds for now. Source: https://github.com/Microsoft/console/issues/68
So with an Insider build of Windows, this will work: 
let &t_SI.="\e[5 q"
let &t_SR.="\e[4 q"
let &t_EI.="\e[1 q"
I'm not sure if they fixed the root issue of not passing ReadConsole state or if they're just fixed the escape sequences. Either way, this is a workaround that can be added to the ConEmu docs: https://conemu.github.io/en/MicrosoftBugs.html#Insert-Overwrite-Indicator. Looks like Microsoft fixed this March 20th. Limited to Insider builds for now. Source: Microsoft/console#68
So with an Insider build of Windows, this will work (added to .vimrc):
let &t_SI.="\e[5 q"
let &t_SR.="\e[4 q"
let &t_EI.="\e[1 q"
I'm not sure if they fixed the root issue of not passing ReadConsole state or if they're just fixed the escape sequences. If it's the latter, explicitly tell vim what you want the cursor set to be you're all set.

I have the same issue with latest ConEmu using Cygwin + Mosh + Tmux. It is

me know what data you need.
. OK. Let me try to describe one of the easiest ways to reproduce this. It is basically the same way as @ndbeals mentioned. I was just too lazy to describe it before he started this thread.
1. Install latest "Cygwin for 64-bit versions of Windows" and ConEmu (currently 150813g 64)
2. Jump into tmux session "tmux attach || tmux new" via ssh from Cygwin64 sh.exe (ConEmu Predefined task is "set CHERE_INVOKING=1 & %ConEmuDrive%\cygwin64\bin\sh.exe --login -i -new_console:C:"%ConEmuDrive%\cygwin64\Cygwin.ico"") and start two vertical windows using [CTRL]+[b], [%] run Midnight Commander "mc" in both
3. Switch to the right window by [CTRL]+[b], [Right] or [Left] if required and press [CTRL]+[o] to hide MC panels which will corrupt the text in left window until you refresh it (see picture below)

Expectations: Text in left window shouldn't be corrupted.
Notes: It is not the only way to reproduce this. There are lots of smal glitches when pseudo-graphical interface like ncurses takes place. ndbeals:
My apologies @Maximus5 , Last night when I made this issue I was quite tired, no excuse for a poor bug report. I'll give a step by step to explain better, requirements are a linux server to connect to via ssh, tmux, htop and a windows machine.
I also tested with every possible combination of different ssh.exe's (ssh.exe from git-for-windows and plink.exe from PuTTY) and different interpreters too (windows conhost.exe (cmd), git-for-windows bash.exe and the sh.exe)
1. Start a ConEmu window using either conhost.exe (one of the default tasks) or bash.exe
2. Using either program, make an ssh connection to a different machine (ssh user@address, nothing fancy)
3. Once connected to a the remote server, install htop and tmux (apt-get install htop tmux)
4. Assuming default tmux commands and controls, start a new tmux session via "tmux new", it should automatically attach you when you create it, if not, use "tmux a" to attach.
5. Once inside tmux, vertically split the view into two command line views by pressing: Control-B to allow tmux commands to be entered, and then press Shift + 5(%) to split them vertically.
6. There should now be a left pane and a right pane, your text input should be focused on the right side pane, if not, switch to it with Control-B + arrow keys.
7. Run the program "htop" in the right pane, some of the output should overlap and break the layout.
8. For definite proof of it breaking, when inside htop, press F1 to go to the htop settings panel, it will certainly break layout then.
I'm also available via slack or gitter or irc if you'd like me to clarify further, I kind of suck at explaining.
Thanks again.

. I find out another parameter that influence on the text representation. Perhaps it will interest you.
It is contrast ration. In my example it is much bellow under recommended level 1.3 vs 4.5. 
There is you can see it: http://leaverou.github.io/contrast-ratio/#rgb%28181%2C137%2C0%29-on-rgb%2849%2C130%2C164%29
More information:
https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG/#visual-audio-contrast
I do not know how to exactly correct such things, but the first idea is dynamically shift the text color to increase the contract value.
e.g. (my case)
bg: rgb(49,130,164), text: rgb(181,137,0), contrast-ratio is 1.3
text 
rgb(181,137,0) -> hsl(45,100%,35%), 
shift the h to reach the maximum contrast-ratio for the current bg,
hsl(63,100%,35%) -> rgb(170,179,0)
result 
bg: rgb(49,130,164), text: rgb(170,179,0), contrast-ratio is 1.9 (not a good, but much more better)
http://leaverou.github.io/contrast-ratio/#rgb%28170%2C179%2C0%29-on-rgb%2849%2C130%2C164%29

dylanaraps:
Support for \033[14t isn't a necessity as we gracefully fallback to displaying ascii art if it isn't available but hearing that the other two are supported is great!
We're using w3m-img to display full-color images in the terminal and the sizing for it takes a pixel w/h value (100x100, etc). What we do with \033[14t is calculate the user's font width/height so that the image sizing can be dynamic based on the terminal window size.
I'll make a note for ConEmu users that they need to use the cygwin/msys connector to get the script to function properly.
Thanks for the speedy reply.
. I just setup the cygwin/msys connecter and everyone is working now!
Support for \033[14t would be nice but it isn't a necessity and if you don't want to add support for it that's fine too.
Thanks for all of the help. :)
. Hey, thanks for implementing \033[14t, I appreciate it!
Because these escape sequences print after the shell prompt we have read the escape sequence as user input. When the escape sequence isn't supported the read loop hangs waiting for user input.
\033[c is more widely supported then \033[14t and \033[6n so we use the output from \033[c as the delimiter in the read loop. This allows the loop to end immediately instead of us using a preset timeout when \033[14t isn't supported. 
It's a little hacky but it works perfectly in every terminal emulator I've tried.
Thanks again for all the help!
.
bisoff:
Проблема общая. под osx определение длины строки prompt тоже съезжает.
История команд тоже портит вывод.
Суть в том что экранирование требуется использовать напрямую, а не через echo в функции или через \$(echo ..).
Если экранирование добавить в echo в функциях то оно выведется как печатные символы.
workaround - не возвращать(печатать через echo) цвет в функции, а сделать напр. так: 
  PS1="[$yellow]\$(git_changed)[$green]\$(git_staged)[$red]\$(git_deleted)[$norm]"
$yellow и т.п. это переменные с цветом: export yellow="\033[0;33;49m").
и в общей библиотеке в вышеупомянутых функциях организовать, если нужно, обрамление пробелами для читаемого вида.
Конечно о динамичной расцветке речи не идёт. Да и не нужно
.

. Sorry for late response, but apparently that commit you made didn't really fix the problem. 
I cannot recall the precise ConEmu version when this changed, but on ver. 160515 [64] {Preview} the situation is following. 
When I type Ctrl+D or exit in the stermc SSH console and I had used Midnight Commander during this session, then CPU usage jumps to 100% and the machine completely stops responding. This, as far as I've found, may be "resolved" only with a hard reset of the PC. I have tried to wait it over, but after 30 minutes nothing's changed, so I still had to hard reset the PC.
ConEmu crash dump doesn't appear after this.
When I type Ctrl+D or exit in the stermc SSH console and Midnight Commander has not been launched during the session, everything's fine.
Also, in case when mc has been launched, closing that tab in ConEmu (i.e. right-click the tab -> Close tab) works fine.
Another note, if I run stermc from standard Windows console, without ConEmu, everything is also fine.
PS: I have a gut feeling that this might somehow be connected with colours, but I cannot really investigate this deeper at the moment. Primarily because of the need to hard-reset very often. I will, however, do anything specific you need me to in order to fix this.
. Another interesting thing I've just found. 
When performing the "worst case scenario" from a default {Shells::cmd} shell inside ConEmu (i.e. manually executing stermc command with proper parameters), then ConEmu process starts using 25% of CPU (a single core, apparently). The machine remains usable in this case, and it's possible to kill ConEmu process via Process Explorer.

. @lennylxx It is not just a wrapper, it IS bash. Try typing bash.exe --help. Many of the traditional bash options found in there will work. As for installing / uninstalling, bash doesn't do that at all. A separate utility called lxrun does all of that with i.a. lxrun /install and lxrun /uninstall. As such, since bash.exe is quite literally bash ported to a windows executable, options like -l -i will work fine in theory. However, as @reflog found out, the -l command will return mesg: /dev/tty: Operation not permitted, probably because Microsoft hasn't implemented handling for that yet.
To resolve this issue, I have personally tried to change most of the keyboard configuration options inside Ubuntu itself to see if it is simply because Ubuntu itself doesn't know how to handle the inputs, but nothing seems to work. I'd assume the issue is that bash.exe expects a format of inputs that only the improved Windows Console Host in this Insider Preview can provide. Adding to that, it's not only the arrow keys that don't work, the del, end, home etc. keys don't work either.
. @Maximus5 Thank you very much for the workaround, it seems to work beautifully!
The only issue that remains is the lack of support for international characters like æøå. This does not work in the official Bash on Ubuntu on Windows either, so I imagine it's up to Microsoft to fix that.

nuclearmistake:
The arrow keys work running Windows 10 bash in a cmd window... and it would appear as though whatever is in between bash.exe and the actual executable is pretty substantial... within the bash shell, there's full-on apt-get (pointed at trusty repos), the windows %PATH% isn't on $PATH, and trying to run notepad.exe from inside bash.exe (...inside cmd.exe) reports that the binary has an unsupported format.
Seems that windows 10 bash is leveraging some of the "new terminal features" that cmd.exe has options for, as it refuses to run if cmd.exe is set to legacy mode... the gist of those features is outlined (for windows server 2016) @ https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt427362.aspx 
. There's a workaround for vim, both local and remote
make sure ctrl+v isn't bound to paste in conemu... use ctrl+shift+v or something.
in local (AND? remote) .bashrc:
if [ -d /mnt/c/WINDOWS ] || [ $LC_WINDOWS10 ]; then
  export WINDOWS10=0
fi
if [ $WINDOWS10 ]; then
  export LC_WINDOWS10=$WINDOWS10
fi
in local (AND? remote) .vimrc:
let windows10=$WINDOWS10
if windows10 == '0'
  set t_ku=(ctrl+v , UP arrow)
  set t_kd=(ctrl+v , DOWN arrow)
  set t_kr=(ctrl+v , RIGHT arrow)
  set t_kl=(ctrl+v , LEFT arrow)
endif
in vim, this will appear as "set t_ku=^[[A" or something like that.
With both the bashrc and vimrc changes in place, local and remote vim both have working arrow keys, without breaking arrow keys in non-windows10 shells.
. not that I've found... maybe in the vanilla windows bash.exe defaults/properties... ctrl+a is similarly ignored for remote byobu+screen sessions :-(

lennylxx:
As far as I know, the C:\Windows\System32\bash.exe is just a wrapper and installer which is used to extract tarball called lxss.tar.gz to C:\Users\<name>\AppData\Local\lxss\rootfs.
It's not an actually Bash at all.
So I don't think adding options like bash.exe -l -i will work, since Microsoft may not have plan to make it compatible with the MSYS2 bash.exe.
Microsoft bash.exe only can be fed one option for now like C:\Windows\System32\bash.exe ~ to start with path navigated to you home directory.
I tried the RealConsole of ConEmu, arrow keys does work in the real console window.
I also read https://github.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/issues/183 and https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/13817, the problem is similar but it seems having different reason.
. @Ordspilleren Yes, you're correct about the installer, I've double checked that. I'm surprised you found the lxrun.exe, didn't notice it before.
But bash.exe IS a wrapper of /bin/bash and feeds all the options to the real bash, because I checked the disassembly of it and I found that it will first launch an installer and then execute /bin/bash in rootfs. You can see a string /bin/bash at address 0xAFA0 using a hex editor.
The 'kernel' which is LxssManager is already running, so we don't need to fully re-implement a bash using WinAPI, just run it on the 'kernel'.
.

rprichard:
FWIW, I just noticed the same problem affecting winpty (https://github.com/rprichard/winpty/issues/82).  It looks like there's a new (undocumented) console input mode flag, 0x200.  When it's enabled, and when certain keys are pressed down, the console generates an escape sequence (encoded as multiple key event records) rather than generate a single bKeyDown=TRUE event record.  The bKeyDown=FALSE record is generated normally, as before.
. @miniksa @Maximus5 FWIW, this VSCode/winpty issue seems related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19665.  ConEmu is broken in exactly the same way (screenshot in this comment, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19665#issuecomment-287248500).  I wrote a test case demonstrating the new (broken?) behavior as of Win10 v15048.. This issue could be responsible for this VSCode issue (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22616).  If I start VSCode from ConEmu (e.g. by running Code.exe), then:

ConEmu does not hook the VSCode processes
The ConEmuANSI variable is set to ON in the VSCode processes.
When VSCode starts its integrated terminal, it uses winpty to create a hidden console (a non-ConEmu "RealConsole").
winpty, unlike ConEmu, does not hook WriteConsole et al to add VT/100 color escape support.
PHP-based components see that ConEmuANSI is set and write escapes, which are visible to the user.

A major caveat: I don't know if this scenario is the one causing the VSCode issue, and it might not be.  It doesn't really matter, though, because I've reproduced it myself.
I'm probably going to end up filtering out ConEmuANSI in winpty, but I still think this is a ConEmu bug..

jonathanlxy:
(I know this comment might look silly, but I have spent 2 days trying to figure out how to setup bash.exe -cur_console:p in Cmder. So I think sharing it here would help someone who is not familiar with ConEmu)
If you want to have WSL bash (with arrow keys issue fixed) as default when Cmder is opened, do the following: 
1. Create a task called whatever you like, e.g. {bash}, in Settings--Tasks, with command %windir%\system32\bash.exe -cur_console:p 
2. In Settings--Startup, select the task you just created as "Specified named task"
3. Save settings, now every time you open Cmder, it automatically runs bash.exe -cur_console:p for you.

Just to be sure that I understand the issue: Git Bash (and other tools) use the terminal mintty to execute console utilities (like vi(m)). As Windows and Unix OS' don't share the same architecture, these console utilities don't have the exact same code base for Windows and Unix. If there is a bug in one of them (like in vi(m)), it's possible that mintty contains some workaround so that this bug isn't experienced when using Git Bash (which uses mintty). As ConEmu doesn't pass its commands through another terminal (like mintty) but uses the console utilities directly, the workaround in mintty isn't applied and the user will experience the bug.
Is that correct?
Thank you for your help! 
P.S.: Updating Git to 2.8.1 solved the issue

frizzr:
More info on this, though I am running an older 150813g (x64) version.
I run ConEmu within a VM, so this problem always seems to occur when the resolution of the display in Windows changes, which I tend to do a lot since I resize my VM window. When I resize my VM window, the screen resolution changes, and the ConEmu window itself is resized. Often I do this accidentally and then restore the VM window to its original setting. 
Even after this accidental VM display resize is done, the child frames never get the message that the window's parent display has changed resolutions (or in this case, the resolution has changed back), and the child frame thinks when the ConEmu window is maximized, that the old, smaller resolution is what it needs to be resized to.
I have found that it often can be made to work properly again by 

Turning off both "Align ConEmu window size to cells" and "Snap to desktop edges"
Setting the ConEmu window to be non-maximized
Resizing the window manually to a slightly larger size by dragging the lower-right corner
THEN you can maximize and it then resizes the child frame properly

It even continues working after turning back on the two settings mentioned in the first step until the resolution of the display changes again.
Hope that helps. Sorry I don't have log files for that, but I could find time later to get those made..

The fact that you have the issue with remote connection and do not have one with local connection suggests that you should check the contents of your TERM environment variable. It is "xterm-256color" for me both locally and remotely.
I do have other issues with ConEmu + cygwin + connector (described here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/conemu_ml/HBTLBzdSUBw) but they do differ from the issue you had reported here.
Having differences in behavior between remote linux and solaris shells also indicates that they are most probably related to the differences in terminfo/termcap databases between your linux and solaris installs. 
. If I were you I would try to fetch termcap and terminfo defs for your TERM from linux server and compile a new test terminal defs on solaris server using them. Read man on tic and infocmp for gory details.
Your best friends would be "infocmp -I", "infocmp -C -r" on the linux side and "mkdir -p ~/.terminfo; tic -o ~/.terminfo/ " on solaris side. Also you would have to change terminal name on solaris side to something sane like "xterm-256color-testing" in the dump file and then execute TERM="xterm-256color-testing" zsh after you had compiled new terminfo definition. In the unlikely case that your term/app use legacy termcap database you should also populate TERMCAP environment variable either with the termcap definition for the terminal (data you get from infocmp -C -r) or put that data into a file and provide full path (i.e. it should start with a "/" character) in the TERMCAP envvar.
I really suspect that the bug you hit is due to some differences between terminfo databases in solaris and linux and it would benefit us all in case you would be able to pinpoint this difference. Comparing linux vs. solaris definitions for your TERM using infocmp would be of a great help here.
. @fpqc While your feature request is perfectly possible to implement I'd doubt that Maximus5 would ever bother to do so: it is a pretty specific functionality that looks more like a hack rather than something else.
As you know X-Server architecture assumes that it would open up arbitrary windows from the client processes that connect to it and these windows are not limited to urxvt - they could easily be something that comes from a remote GUI app you had started up over ssh while using XForwarding. Even if you would launch xserver as a ConEmu child process there would be no sane way to distinguish between (u)rxvt windows and any other app windows you might encounter.
On the other hand you could possibly automate this using AutoIt or some other similar software. You would have to implement a script that would look for windows spawned by xserver process and having something related to rxvt in their title and then perform a macro that would attach found window as a ChildGUI app into your ConEmu session.
I don't know if there is an API of some sort in ConEmu that allows to easily automate "Attach..." operation. If not - then that is a valid feature request IMO for ConEmu to provide such an API for third party use. It could be a command line utility of some sort or a reaction to a custom windows message sent to ConEmu using SendMessage/PostMessage windows API. In reality details are not so important and should be defined by the implementing person.
. @fpqc Ough, and forgot to mention that XMing is an old (and a bit commercial) thing and there are more recent alternatives that could suit you better, like this: https://sourceforge.net/projects/vcxsrv/
. @Maximus5 
Issue poster actually requests you to implement ZModem protocol in ConEmu. Don't know if you were around back in early-to-mid nineties when there were no internet and people were using modems to dial into BBS and upload/download some files. It is typical for terminal emulator (which ConEmu actually is) to support legacy transport protocols like X/Y/ZModem or Kermit. ZModem is best of them all as it supports transfer auto-startup, multiple files transfer in one session, automatic file name transfer, download resuming after crash and some more nice features.
Personally I don't see a real reason to use ZModem nowdays when we use reliable transports like TCP streams instead of serial links and there are a lot of other well established file transfer protocols (ftp, sftp, scp, rsync and many more). Also implementing ZModem in ConEmu would be a painful task to deal with as windows console concept is totally different to stdin/stdout concept used by serial links (and ZModem). 
TL/DR: I don't think this feature request is worth spending development efforts on. Using ssh for remote server access and sz for file transfer over ssh IMO is a rare usage pattern which contradicts with the modern ways of doing the same things (though I see one reason for this - simplicity, type in "sz myfile" and there you go). 
. Small followup: the only place where it would be easier to fit ZModem w.r.t. ConEmu is a cygwin connector. Still don't think this would be a good idea as it would unnecessarily complicate connector without much practical benefit.

Git for Windows which is mentioned as a working example of the new functionality most probably uses bash/mintty (at least it was like that with older Git for Windows releases) so terminal emulation and presentation is handled by mintty (and not conhost!). So it is not a surprise that italic and strikeout work there.

AndyScull:
From what I know, japanese letters and general symbols they use start from 0x3000.
I used http://unicode-table.com/en/ to try few different ranges and see what results I'll get.
Keep in mind I kept using MS Gothic font, so many characters were shown as squares (but behavior of those squares were different)
0180 range - Latin Extended - do not have problems whatsoever
0370 - Greek characters - no problems
Arabic-like languages skipped, since they're right-to-left and symbols appear at start of filename despite being typed in the end
0e00 - Thai - no problems
1800 - Mongolian - no problem, except font drawing changes for whole filename, if there are visible Mongolian characters in line. If characters are cut off (left panel made narrower) - font returns to normal
1E00 - Latin Extended Additional - My font cannot show them, but squares do not jump around as I change panel width, and I believe they would show fine if I used compatible font
2c60 - Latin Extended-C - same as above
2E80 - CJK radicals - the problem I mentioned appears.
Basically, to replicate this you can:
1. set font to something supporting japanese (if you use random font, japanese character would still be shown using substitute font and won't be consistent with ascii characters)
2. create folder/file named "世界中のあらゆる情報を検索するためのツールを提供しています。さまざまな検索機能 を活用して、お探しの情報を見つけてください" (random string from google)
3. change Far panel width using alt+left, alt+right  and see how file name behaves. If it's shorter than file panel - then everything is alright. When you shrink the panel, letters are being compressed too forcefully and in the end you have to enable monowidth to be able to distinguish characters

1. Didn't you say that proper width for DBCS characters is 2 cells? You meant character placeholders, like 80x25 in oldschool default console size, or is it something else?

ConEmu would just 'convert' existing strings to proper unicode glyphs, using whatever font is specified in settings. in process, shrinking whole line of text as lot of glyphs are less than 2 cells wide
7. Then you'll get a situation like in my screenshot - where 30 characters are printed aligned to left, and a lot of space because FAR provided only those 30 chars and nothing more

I have managed to figure out that:
a) When I right-click to paste it uses Multi-Line mode (even if I am pasting a single line with no line breaks), and this hasn't been fixed yet because (based off your commit message) your fix is only for single line mode.

MetricMike:
Also running into the same issue. For context, I think jgoz and I are both using prezto themes (I'm pretty sure he's using sorin's and I'm on paradox) that take advantage of zsh's right-hand prompt. The way I've seen it described, most themes that take advantage of a right-hand and left-prompt on the same line do math in a before block to calculate the needed padding.
I've tried several prompts that only use the left-hand prompt or a "static" combined prompt (I'm making up terms here, pls forgive) and they don't appear to have this issue. The Sorin and Paradox themes use a "dynamic" combined prompt that I think is redrawing the entire line with new padding everytime it receives a character.

Sorin and Paradox are disagreeing on how big the line actually is, but neither are rendering spaces at the correct width.

Paradox:

@Maximus5 No, no. I'm talking about the associated windows in Xming (a windows X Server).  The WSL process is irrelevant.
For example, it's just like if I was running Xming and Cygwin, and I opened up Xterm in cygwin and it opened up an Xterm window in my local Xserver (Xming).  In ConEMU, the process is listed as being type "GUI" and the Image name is Xming.exe.
I can manually attach and detach the windows from ConEMU.
This should be under other-childgui.
. Xming is a server runs in the system tray as a persistent executable listening on localhost and creates windows when requested by applications (i.e. X clients) connect.  
For each application (X client) that looks for DISPLAY=# (where # is set in the Xming (or in general any X server), you get an Xming window open. However, there is only one Windows process (xming.exe) running at a time.

Vim bell: edit $HOME/.vimrc
set visualbell.

I had/have a nearly identical problem which started at almost the same time, I'm fairly certain I caused it and it isn't a problem of ConEmu's (excellent software by the way, I've been using it for sysadmin for over a year now). I managed to change something that affects asynchronous file transfer, and managed to get ConEmu to download by adding th "-async n" switch to the external downloader line on the update page in ConEmu's settings. 
eg.""%ConEmuBaseDir%\ConEmuC64.exe" -download -async n %1 %2"
Now Conemu downloads fine, but I'm still not sure how the problem started in the first place.

-c means the command cd ~ is executed at bash startup. Of course you can set any command as you like.`
. @NitroBAY Ops, I made a mistake. 
The Windows file system is mounted to Windows Subsystem For Linux(WSL) on /mnt. For example, C:\Users\ is mapped to /mnt/C/Users. So on WSL, you can cd to /mnt/C/Users to access C:\Users\.
In order to make bash cd to particular directory, there are multiple ways. 
- On WSL side, you can add cd /home/NitroBAY/projects to the bottom of your .bashrc or .zshrc file in your home directory. 
- If you want to configure on ComEmu side, you can use "-new_console:d:C:\Users\llan\"%windir%\system32\bash.exe -cur_console:p for example. In this way, if you specify a path inside WSL, C:\Users\llan\AppData\Local\lxss\home\NitroBAY\projects for example, it always redirect to /. 
- The third method, you can configure on ComEmu like %windir%\system32\bash.exe -cur_console:p -c "cd /home/NitroBAY/projects && bash", I missed out bash at first. It might not be a good way, but it works. 
.

DerrickRice:
For other folks who come across this in attempts to Google a solution, here's the one that worked best for me. I changed the /etc/profile of the WSL to add these lines to the bottom:
if [ "$SHLVL" ] && [ "$SHLVL" = "1" ]; then
  cd ~
fi
For whatever reason, bash.exe is implicitly a login shell. There's no need to add --login to the command line. Per bash documentation, a login shell will source /etc/profile first. I found it helpful to use this as the earliest possible opportunity to fix the incorrect starting directory. It only does so when it's not a nested shell. That is, it's a shell that's started by ConEmu (or some other entity external from the WSL).
Note that you cannot otherwise specify to bash.exe that it should go to a different WSL directory. The "cd && bash -i" trick has subtle failings..
nostyia: Putting @DerrickRice code into profile doesn't work for me, but if i put into .bashrc in home/user directory close and open bash work properly.
andrewfinnell:
As I am integrating WSL within VS Code I thought I would share what I found to work (for now anyways).
bash -c "cd /c/Users && bash --init-file ~/.bash_profile"
Granted this isn't accepting any arguments and may be fraught with Environment setup issues. It may be possible to create a Workspace .bash_profile for each project one is using that changes the cwd to the project's directory instead. Then the launching command can always be the same:
Use Case:

Create a .wsl directory in the root of your project folder.
Create a new .bash_profile file with the project settings required and changing the directory if needed.
Add a Terminal Launch string as follows: bash -c "cd . && bash --init-file ./.wsl/.bash_profile"

When the Terminal is launched it should source the local .bash_profile file. That file can then source a user common bash profile such as `~/.bash_profile' or such.
Perhaps this all is a non-issue now but I did come across something similar which is how I ended up here. I hope this can help anyone using ConEmu and WSL.
.

If you guys are using wslbridge in your task as specified on this page for proper ANSI colors, you can use -C per wslbridge help
```
Usage: /wsl/wslbridge [options] [--] [command]...
Runs a program within a Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) pty
Options:
  -C WSLDIR     Changes the working directory to WSLDIR first.
                An initial '~' indicates the WSL home directory.
  -e VAR        Copies VAR into the WSL environment.
  -e VAR=VAL    Sets VAR to VAL in the WSL environment.
  -T            Do not use a pty.
  -t            Use a pty (as long as stdin is a tty).
  -t -t         Force a pty (even if stdin is not a tty).
```

set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt -C "~"

parkerault:
Since this is now the top search result for "conemu wsl startup directory" and the comments are a little noisy; the solution is to add -C "~" to the end of your commands string. If you select the {WSL:bash} task in Startup > Tasks the command text box should look like this:
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt -C "~".

jdunn0:
I have this same issue, I just never got around to filling the bug.
I found out what seems to be the problem.
When ConEmu starts KiTTY with the -load option, this process tree appears under ConEmu64.exe:
- ConEmuC.exe
  - conhost.exe
  - kitty.exe
The processes ConEmuC.exe inherits the Environment Variables from ConEmu64.exe and the process conhost.exe inherits the Environment Variables from ConEmuC.exe
However the kitty.exe process doesn't inherit any Environment Variables from ConEmuC.exe which leaves the process with no Environment Variables set at all.
I looked online and it appears the Networking Errors that KiTTY shows can be caused by incorrect Environment Variables.
I just checked and the same issue of no Environment Variables being inherited also affects putty.exe but for whatever reason, this doesn't cause any issues with PuTTY at all.
This issue did not happen for me until after I installed the Windows 10 Anniversary Update so I think it may have changed something that caused this to happen.
I found the above information about Environment Variables by looked at the "Environment Variables" tab in Process Explorer for each process.
Post Comment Note:
After I wrote the above I decided to try Process Explorer and found that that for the kitty.exe and putty.exe processes, the Environment Variables are inherited but that information just cannot be accessed without running the Process Manger program with Administrator Privileges.
I would guess the processes themselves also can't access their own Environment Variables either based on this problem but I'll need to look into this later.
I did try running ConEmu with Administrator Privileges but it didn't change anything.
So I would guess at the moment that the Windows 10 Anniversary update did something to the API used by ConEmu to launch Child Processes that changes the permissions on inherited Environment Variables.
I'm not sure though, it's bizarre behavior that is hard to figure out.

. You can read some info on ConEmuHk at https://conemu.github.io/en/ConEmuHk.html.
It appears the main point of it is to hook some Windows APIs which allow ConEmu to do things that otherwise can't be done and to deal with bugs in Windows.
You can disable ConEmuHk by going to the features section of ConEmu settings and unchecking "Inject ConEmuHk".
. Are you sure the ConEmu Window is not just minimized?
The default behavior for Taskbar Icons in Windows 7 and Up for single window programs is this:
If the program is not running then clicking the Icon will run the program.
If the program is running, not in focus and/or minimized then clicking the icon will unminimize (if needed) and/or focus the program's Window.
If the program is running and is in focus then clicking the icon will minimize the program's Windows.

1. Disable ‘Default Terminal’ feature if you use it. (OK)
2. Press Win+R and run your console application. (OK: C:\Program Files\Git\git-cmd.exe --no-cd --command=usr/bin/bash.exe -l -i  )

5. Ensure that console window buffer and window width and height are the same as in ConEmu (you may check them in StatusBar). (OK, although probably not relevant in this case)

```
$ git --version
git version 2.10.0.windows.1
$ ssh -V
OpenSSH_7.3p1, OpenSSL 1.0.2h  3 May 2016
```
. ### I found the culprit
In order to make UTF-8 output work in my terminal (output from gradle for instance) I had switched my terminal into UTF-8 mode by putting this under ConEmu Environment:
chcp utf-8
As it turns out, if I remove this line, accents work again while under ssh. But then removing it will also break my gradle terminal output which is utf-8... bummer.
_Additional comments_
From this I gather that what I put in ConEmu Environment gets executed even when I attach external consoles?
As a workaround for when I need chcp utf8 stuff, what would you recommend?
$ set ConEmuCpCvt=gradlew:850:65001;
?
Thanks again for your time!
. > Thats why I mention same conditions of fair comparison. https://conemu.github.io/en/ThirdPartyProblems.html#stand-alone

I believe, if you execute "chcp 65001" in standalone prompt and execute ssh - you'll get the same problem without ConEmu. Than it's obviously an ssh bug.

karliss:
This project can be used to directly control console mode without messing with bash.exe.
. It could be more difficult than that. Warning I am not too familiar with insides of ConEmu so I might be wrong. From what I understand ConEmu can obtain application output in two ways: stdout from proper console application, hook into windows console API calls like WriteConsole.
It seems that bash.exe is not a proper console application, it can be tested by running bash.exe -c ls > a1.txt. Doing that results in "Error: 0x80070057" being written to a1.txt. Using lxlaunch has similar results when trying to pass a handle to file instead of console screen buffer.  
As for second case I am guessing that writes are done in a different process not bash.exe/lxlaunch making it difficult for ConEmu to hook into WriteConsole calls.
I was able to get some of the ANSI codes recognized by manually reading data from console screen buffer using ReadConsoleOutputCharacter and then printing it to stdout.

. I agree that this is wrong.  For arbitrary program using Windows console API there is no way of knowing which parts of buffer were updated, and where. I did it mostly to confirm that ConEmu isn't processing ANSI codes because actual writes to console buffer are done somewhere else where hook can't observe it, instead of not having correct mode enabled. 
At the moment I have SetConsoleMode(outHandle, DISABLE_NEWLINE_AUTO_RETURN). And I do reads from position 0;0, and reset cursor to 0;0 after each read. It worked better than I expected, probably because WLS is using mostly ANSI codes directly to change the position instead of Windows API.

. It seems that the way unicode describes bidirectional text printing characters in correct order requires knowing full text (chunk of text) in advance. That is not really practical for terminal. Printing characters incrementally can change positions of previously printed characters. 
From the look of https://www.arabeyes.org/ArabeyesTodo#Terminal_Emulators no one really knows how bidirectional text should interact with various terminal control characters like moving/reading cursor position, clearing until end of line and others. What happens you replace character in the middle of previously printed text? . Turns out ECMA-48 standard has a little bit of information about how bi-directional text should interact with terminal control sequences. http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/Ecma-048.pdf 
Haven't read it carefully so I can't comment if it's usable, implementable and how well it matches the bi-directional text logic that was added to unicode after it was written..

MGtB:
To start a terminal with 24-bit colour, without any external scripts as @antitoxic was trying to do, create a task with the following command:
echo [9999H & set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt -new_console:h9999
Where the  is the ESC character that you can copy from SetEscChar.cmd
@Maximus5 would you mind explaining what this magic echo [9999H does? It's obviously related to buffer size we set with -new_console:h9999, but I don't understand what it does. Thanks!.

The related windows issue https://github.com/Microsoft/console/issues/68 has been fixed in Windows 10 version 1809 (Build 17763.194). Running bash.exe directly (not through ConEmu), the cursor changes in insert mode:
Normal Mode

Insert Mode

@Maximus5 Not sure if this fixes the root issue you mentioned before that prevents ConEmu from accessing the Real Console state. Any plans to look into this in light of this new fix?
. I have created a workaround for this. Sticking this into your .vimrc will get your cursor to switch between block and beam for normal mode and insert mode respectively:
```
if has("autocmd")
   let conEmuMacro = "!/mnt/c/utils/ConEmu/ConEmu/ConEmuC64.exe -guimacro setoption check"
   let beamCursor = conEmuMacro . " 2531 " . "1 >/dev/null 2>&1 &"
   let blockCursor = conEmuMacro . " 2532 " . "1 >/dev/null 2>&1 &"
au VimLeave * silent execute beamCursor | redraw!
   au VimEnter * silent execute blockCursor | redraw!
au InsertEnter * silent execute beamCursor | redraw!
   au InsertLeave * silent execute blockCursor | redraw!
endif
``
You need to change this linelet conEmuMacro = "!/mnt/c/utils/ConEmu/ConEmu/ConEmuC64.exe ....` to point to your ConEmuC executable. 
This basically utilizes a combination of Vim auto-commands and ConEmu GUI macros to force ConEmu to change the cursor shape when Vim enters or leaves insert mode. Forcing Vim to redraw the screen (the redraw! above) is necessary after the cursor change, otherwise you will get screen artifacts. 
Needless to say that this is a hack and forcing Vim to clean and redraw the screen each time you enter and leave insert mode like that causes a delay in your workflow.
. If you are using Vim with WSL, there was a known WSL issue https://github.com/Microsoft/console/issues/68. That issue was fixed in a recent Windows 10 update. However, I don't know if this fix will enable ConEmu to detect the cursor change from the "Real Console". Perhaps @Maximus5 can shed more light on that. More details and a hacky workaround here https://github.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/issues/937#issuecomment-446834709..

OddMorning:
I just encountered that problem and made a workaround that seems to be working
Add to ~/.bash_aliases
```
"clear" command that "supports" 24bit colors
alias clear='clear; echo -ne "\e[32766H\e[$((LINES - 1))A"'
```
Add to ~/.bashrc
```
Clear the screen, scroll beyond limits, and set cursor at the first visible line
clear; echo -ne "\e[32766H\e[$((LINES - 1))A"
Bind Ctrl+L to alias
bind -x '"\C-l": clear'
``
Now bash echoes the prompt beyond limits and bothclearandCtrl+l` work properly.

P.S. That thing also enables support of bold and italic fonts! I thought they're completely dead on windows but it suddenly turned out they're not (normal console on top, console after \033[9999H on bottom):

P.S.S. Airline (aka powerline) for Vim can display bold font but it doesn't look like it scrolls screen 9999 lines down. How's did they do that?

. Oh, now I see what alternative mode means, thanks!

ConEmu buffer may be greater than 9999 lines

I'm aware of that limitation and originally tried to use \e[32999H but any value bigger than 32768 behaves like 0.
But I just made some more tests and it turned out that “working area” starts not after last buffer line, but after last buffer line minus screen height. I.e. set window height to 30 lines, buffer size to 1000 lines, then scroll 970 lines down, and lines between 970 and 1000 still render bold/italic font and 24bit colored cubes properly.
In short, \e[32766H\e[${LINES}A will work for every buffer size (I hope) so I edited my comment above.. @nickbudi Hmm, you're right, first line doesn't display 256 colors. But I just figured why, that was my mistake. \e[32766H moves cursor to the buffer + line count line and \e[${LINES}A moves cursor line count lines up. But I did not take into account current cursor position which shouldn't be included in line count so it moved cursor to the last line of the buffer area.
In short,  \e[32766H\e[$((LINES - 1))A should work with first line too (at least it does for me)..

I need to set the cmder / conemu exe to launch as an administrator.
https://python-forum.io/Thread-How-to-become-Administrator-once-in-Command-Prompt

Right click on cmder.exe --> properties --> Change setup for all users --> Run this program as administrator --> mark on V
This will ensure future requests for admin privileges work .

maggu:
Yes, I can see how efficient it would be if it works for you. For me it doesn't, unfortunately.
Basically, I want to make it work the way my brain expects it too. I don't want to be surprised that I pasted when I didn't intend to.
In pretty much every program there is, right clicking opens a menu. I also work a lot in OS X and Linux. I copy and paste between OS X and Windows (through Synergy). In Terminal.app, right clicking opens a menu. In every terminal program I've used on OS X and Linux, right clicking opens a menu.
So personally I feel that right clicking to paste badly breaks "the principle of least surprise". I don't want to have to stop and think about what OS and program I'm in at the moment, and how copy/paste might work in that particular environment.. I would pretty much expect it to work the way the "Edit" menu in ConEmu currently does. You might call it a shortcut. I would like the same options if I right click as if I had clicked on the system menu and chosen "Edit".


there is no selection, there is text in buffer


"Copy" is greyed out. If I "Paste" the text in the clipboard is pasted.


there is no selection and clipboard is empty (rare)


"Copy" is greyed out. Nothing happens if I "Paste".


there is active selection, there is text in clipboard


I can choose "Copy" to copy selection to buffer. If I "Paste" the text in the clipboard is pasted and the selection disappears.


there is active selection and clipboard is empty (rare)


I can choose "Copy" to copy selection to clipboard. If I "Paste" nothing is pasted and the selection disappears.
I fail to see why it would make no sense or be bad behaviour. It's a different way to work. How can it be bad behaviour when more or less every Windows program works that way?
If I don't want "Copy on Left Button Release" enabled, it's another alternative to using the middle button to copy or navigating through the system menu every time.
In general, it could also enable a whole set of other features. For example, if "GitHub" is the active selection, the option 'Find text...' might change to 'Find "GitHub"'. But even if no such additional features were to be implemented, the option to open a menu would make the behaviour consistent with other software..
