Seems to work fine in current version, thanks. Yeah, it seems this was fixed now. Well, actually it uses a native library to determine whether the console is attached to a terminal or not. The project is https://github.com/adammurdoch/native-platform, the corresponding code that returns false is https://github.com/adammurdoch/native-platform/blob/master/src/main/cpp/win.cpp#L404-L419.. I also reported it at adammurdoch/native-platform#26 now in case it is more a problem of the detection process, but I'm still not sure which side is causing this.. Ah, so it IS the detection that is erroneous, because it does not do the correct checks when run in the Connector or in Git Bash and thus msys, right? Can you tell me how the detection has to be done properly?. No, the check tries to determine whether a terminal is attached to the streams. If a terminal is attached, there is e. g. progress information and colors shown. If no terminal is attached, e. g. stdout is piped to another command, no progress information is displayed and no colors are shown.
Besides that, a ConEmu specific solution is probably not the best solution if the reason it is not working correctly is the same as for Git Bash and there could be a way used that works for this situation.. It is not my tool, I'm just a user and sometimes contributor. Just searching for a solution I could suggest and you sounded like you could have an idea. :-) . Ah, great, thanks. Having a setting is fine.
I'd expect it to keep the old behavior as default setting if it had a switch, so I didn't search for it.
I'm happy again now. :-).

kirillkh:
@hsab I tried several workarounds, none worked satisfactorily except the following: 
1) download and install wsltty, a special mintty build https://github.com/mintty/wsltty
2) setup the "wsltty" task as follows: %LOCALAPPDATA%\wsltty\bin\mintty.exe --wsl -o Locale=C -o Charset=UTF-8 /bin/wslbridge -t /bin/bash -l
3) enable the "Install keyboard hooks" option in Settings -> Keys & Macro -> Keyboard
4) change the keyboard shortcuts for "Switch next console" and "Switch previous console" to Win+PgUp and Win+PgDown (or Win+other keys that you prefer).
Basically, this embeds mintty into ConEmu. The disadvantage is that you cannot use the tab switching shortcut that you're used to, but are forced to use Win+PgUp/Down and similarly with other ConEmu shortcuts (which I don't use). But it's okay-ish for me as a temporary solution until Windows fixes their console.. > Which exactly?

warrenfalk: While we're all talking about using "Kill active process" as a workaround, I want to remind that it is not the same as "Ctrl+C".  Kill works if all you need to do is make the process die, but Ctrl+C gives active processes an opportunity to do a clean shutdown, whereas kill just yanks the rug out from underneath it.  This difference affects me a lot because the processes I'm running have to run a recovery on startup if they don't shut down cleanly..

Why so much thumbs down guys? using the connector fully resolved the issue for me!
diff
- set CHERE_INVOKING=1 & %ConEmuDrive%\Portable\git\usr\bin\bash.exe --login -i -new_console:C:"%ConEmuDrive%\Portable\git\usr\share\git\git-for-windows.ico"
+ set CHERE_INVOKING=1 & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-msys2-64.exe %ConEmuDrive%\Portable\git\usr\bin\bash.exe --login -i -new_console:C:"%ConEmuDrive%\Portable\git\usr\share\git\git-for-windows.ico" . Well, the only drawback is that now i always get this dialog upon wanting to close conemu:

That "incomplete operation" being obviously the spawn bash.exe process.. Er... i'm afraid i've now stumbled upon a very unfortunate issue by using the connector :-(
```bash
$ git commit -a -S -m "updated semantics"
gpg: Fatal: WriteConsole failed: 102 != 101
error: gpg failed to sign the data
fatal: failed to write commit object
```. I ended disabling the connector and decreasing the buffered height lines to 2800 within conemu and all good now.
Whoever made the vim.exe port needs to fix it, conemu rocks :). np @pfeiferbit glad i was of help :).

splitice:
Actually the window does not resize automatically, thats the problem.
Normally one of two things happen with the on-screen keyboard:
1. If not maximized, window is resized to not be overlayed by the keyboard; or
2. If maximised keyboard is overlayed. Control (i.e textbox) is focused if supported (automatically scrolled).
Due to this being a more complex application that doesn't happen and instead the keyboard overlays the writing area.... making it useless.
In tablet mode (no keyboard) all windows are maximized by default.
I believe the correct approach would be to detect the appropriate size of the keyboard, then resize the command content / control.
This is all with the Windows 10 keyboard that docks to the bottom of the screen, what I assume you mean by "full size".. Unfortunately the screenshot button (power + volume up) hides the keyboard.
Heres a relatively low quality video - https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/62365823/2017-02-14%2008.34.13.mp4
It would be great if Windows behaved differently here... but they don't..

pkasting:
I can reproduce this issue with 161206.
If I double-click a word and immediately press middle mouse, I get my previous clipboard contents on that and all future pastes.  If I double-click, wait about a half second, and then press middle mouse, I get the updated clipboard contents on that and all future pastes.
Attaching an image of my settings.  I do not have "reset selection on left button release" set.
. So "auto" means "immediately copy the selection to the clipboard, then paste it"?  I could live with that.
Out of curiosity, why not copy as soon as you have a changed, non-empty selection due to a mouse event, instead of waiting for a timer (presumably, a timer set to the system double-click time)?  In that case, if the user is triple-clicking (for example), you'd copy immediate on double-click and then copy again on triple-click, which seems OK.. "auto" seems to cause unpredictable behavior:
 Sometimes, middle-clicking clears the current selection without pasting anything, then clicking again pastes.
 Sometimes, middle-clicking (quickly after double-clicking) pastes the current selection once, but repeated clicks paste the old clipboard contents (so, basically, the middle click did not force a clipboard update, and the selection was cleared before the timer kicked off).
I agree that "reset on copy" is incompatible with automatically copying.  I don't have a solution to that, other than to not do the behavior I'm proposing in that case.  OTOH, the other objections you raise seem to be addressable.  (I'm one of the folks who's worked on clipboard implementation stuff in Google Chrome, so I'm not entirely unfamiliar with this space.)  Copying does take time, but not enough time to actually notice when triggered by user actions (since those are comparatively slow and infrequent).  Copying does alert other applications monitoring the clipboard, but that's sort of desirable in this case.  I'm not sure what would cause a failure to copy twice; maybe if a monitoring app reads the clipboard change and modifies the clipboard on a timer itself?  But in that case it would interfere with copying once too.  As for copying not being required if you paste immediately, the problem there is that the pasted text wouldn't reflect the clipboard state, so (as noted above) repeated pastes don't get the same value.
Basically, I'm attempting to reproduce a typical Linux bash environment, where middle-mouse would cause the current selection to be copied to the clipboard immediately and then pasted.  It seems like "auto" doesn't quite do that, and "paste" doesn't work because copying isn't auto-triggered on mouse-based selection changes.  I don't know how else to achieve this.. I see.  I don't want either of those behaviors, so it sounds like auto is not for me.
I don't know if you have any proposal for how to better emulate the Linux sort of behavior via the "paste" mechanism.. I installed it, but it doesn't seem to fix my testcase:

Select some text with left-drag
Immediately press middle-click to paste

Expected: Selected text is pasted
Actual: Previous clipboard contents are pasted. Using that, the mouse buttons don't have the same functions as in my case, but I still see a delay-based difference:

Select some text with left-drag
Left-click once to cancel dragging
Right-click to paste text

When doing all three steps in very rapid succession, the pasted text is the previous clipboard contents.  If I wait a bit after the initial left-drag, the pasted text is the dragged text..

AquaeAtrae:
@Maximus5 Thanks for all your hard work here. :)
I'm glad to hear this was fixed for "Bash on Ubuntu on Windows". I do see it works correctly when using bash.exe or wsl.exe directly. 
However, the only documented method to show 256-colors involves calling scripts (a .cmd script which starts wslbridge and runs a .sh script within it). So understandably, we can no longer close the window without it thinking that I still have an incomplete process (the scripts).
I don't understand how wsl-con.cmd and its escape sequence (\e[9999H) enables 256 colors through the hidden RealConsole to appear properly within ConEmu. However, after a lot of experimentation I found a simpler method that works great. However, it only works once. The required Escape character is replaced with a "?" after closing ConEmu. 
Can you fix the Task settings to permanently store all (unicode) characters including this Escape character? And can you document this or a better solution for those of us using WSL?
Here's the method's I've seen in your current documentation.
Closes nicely but only 16 colors...
based on "Preferred way to run WSL" .
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pnm:/mnt -t bash
256 colors but appears as an Incomplete Operation when closing...
based on "How to get 24-bit colors working" which runs wsl-con.cmd and then wsl-boot.sh within WSL.
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl\wsl-con.cmd -run
SUCCESS (...TEMPORARILY)
As I was working on documenting this, I believe I've come up with a Task definition that successfully accomplishes everything without the additional script layers. I'm posting the method I used in hopes that you and others might be able to reproduce my results.
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & echo [9999H & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pnm:/mnt -C~ -t bash
IMPORTANT: "echo {escape char}[9999H" is the actual escape character (Alt 027) which others can copy and paste from here since github won't present it as is.
https://i.imgur.com/CCARyWx.png
ConEmu 171025 [64]
Linux Mist 4.4.0-17134-Microsoft #112-Microsoft Thu Jun 07 22:57:00 PST 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
Description:    Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS
. PS: I think I found a permanent solution that works despite special characters getting lost from the Settings. I do still suggest that would be good to fix as it may affect some with different languages and character sets.
Rather than present the magic escape sequence from Windows, I found it also works coming from within the WSL shell. (Again, I have no idea what it actually does to affect the colors.) 
So I simplified my Start Task even further to be...
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pnm:/mnt -C~ -t bash -l -i
Then, to enable true color support, I added the following line to my .bashrc file.
```
Enables 256-color (true color) for ConEmu
echo -e '\e[9999H'
```
If you use zsh or fish in your Start Task, just add this to .zshrc or .fishrc (I believe).
SUCCESS (ALWAYS!)
And that seems to do the trick. I can now see 256 colors and can immediately close the wslbridge window as expected..

KuromiAK commented on 7 May:
After some testing (161206 stable), it appears that ConEmu is confused by character '➜' (arrow in robbyrussell), '' (powerline arrow) and '' (powerline branch symbol). The symbols are supposed to be 1 character wide but ConEmu advances cursor by 2 characters when they are inputed. ConEmu also only retracts by 1 character when these symbols are deleted.

I can confirm the issue only appears with oh-my-zsh theme enabled.
Is there any plan to fix this?
As workaround, just copy the theme to custom directory, and drop or replace the characters fix this..

akomakom:
In case it's useful, my AutoHotKey workaround:
1. Set hotkeys (All are Win+Ctrl+Shift):
- z: focus to ConEmu
- x: focus to child
- PgDn: Switch previous console
- PgUp: Switch next console
2. AutoHotKey Script:
```
IfWinActive ahk_class VirtualConsoleClass
^+PgUp::Send, {shift down}{ctrl down}{lwin down}z{PgUp}{lwin up}{ctrl up}{shift up}
^+PgDn::Send, {shift down}{ctrl down}{lwin down}z{PgDn}{lwin up}{ctrl up}{shift up}
IfWinActive
```
This assigns next/previous to Ctrl+Shift+PgUp and Ctrl+Shift+PgDn (^+ = Ctrl+Shift), and when pressed it changes focus to ConEmu and presses Win+Ctrl+Shift+PgUp/Down (which are the keys we configured above).  You could also add "x" after PgUp and PgDn (eg: "..z{PgUp}x...") to move focus back to child, but I haven't found it to be necessary (it happens anyway).. That said, I do not entirely agree on the bad UX.  Since ConEmu has a feature to attach random windows to the tabbed view, I'd still opt for the ability to enforce some level of global hotkey control over the tabs.  The Win-Q and Win-# hotkey option is nice, but not very flexible, and I don't see why it couldn't be configurable, but then again I'm not familiar with the code..

pingzing:
Apologies, there's one extra reproduction step I forgot to mention:
3.5. In tmux, enable mouse mode with tmux set mouse. 
This will enable mousewheel scrolling.. While not a ConEmu feature, this is a somewhat common thing, especially in UNIX-land. One solution that works well for PowerShell would be to do something like this:
PowerShell
your-long-running-exe.exe; [console]::beep(500, 300)
The semicolon ensures that the beep() will be run after your .exe completes. The first argument to beep() is the pitch, and the second is the duration in milliseconds.
Note: For this work, you have to have "Suppress bells" disabled in ConEmu. You can find that checkbox in Settings -> Features, and the underneath the "In-console options" section, on the far right.

. @Maximus5 It seems that the culprit here is the set -s escape-time 0 in .tmux.conf!

escape-time time
Set the time in milliseconds for which tmux waits after an escape is input to determine if it is part of a function or meta key sequences. The default is 500 milliseconds.

This escape-time is often set to 0 in tmux to avoid lagging with vim, but I guess here it didn't let the mouse click time to "finish"... clicking? Putting it to 20 ms seems to do the job without making vim lag too much.

yuzvir: I've found the quick workaround for this. You can fix PE Header in nvim.exe and change its Subsystem from 'Windows Console' (3) to 'Windows GUI' (2). It can be easily made by any hexeditor, just change the byte at position 0xDC from 0x03 to 0x02.
ddiukariev:
I have the same issue. Makes it hard to use vim in comemu as on scroll half of the screen just goes blank. I was unable to reproduce using standard cmd/powershell and console2. I'm running vim for windows.. Some more info on the issue. I was able to narrow it down a bit. It is reproduced only when scroll step (:set scroll=) is greater than 50% of lines visible. So e.g. i have 69 lines fit into visible area. As soon as I set scroll step to 35 I start getting redraw issue. But I do not get it if I set 34 and below. I also noticed that when I resize conEmu the vim setting (set scroll) gets automatically updated. And looks like it tries to keep this value to match 50% of lines visible but sometimes seems to set value higher than 50% and that when issue emerges.. I found a fix. There are number of options available for vim that control how it behaves when sending output to terminal. So it seems that defaults just doesn't work well with conEmu. So to fix the issue just use :set ttyscroll=0 (actually you can set to higher value for details read docs on option). 
Also Maximus5 if you can, it would be nice if you read chapter 4 at http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/term.html and maybe you can suggest some better way to fix it.. I use official. No xterm emulation.

Ryonez:
Ugh, what a mess. I can barely tell what is happening.
I think @tstauffer ended up with what I'm facing.
Basicly, if you open ComEmu with a something like a bat file, or a specific task, it'll try to run that bat or task again when you try to create a new console via Win +x, or by clicking this 

 button.
So in my case I have my computer run a .bat file when it boots to start speedfan. ConEmu hooks it, and when you try to to make a new console, ConEmu will start and load the .bat file again. Basically, it'll always run the last command in a new console.
It doesn't seem to happen is you open a shell specifically, like when you open one in here:

To fix this, you can set a default task to be used instead.
Open the options, then click settings:

Then got to tasks (Under Startup), select the task/shell you want as default, then click default task for new console.

Now whenever you open a new console, it won't rerun the last task it did, like that pesky startup bat file that only needed to be used once. >.<
Note, even though it won't open the .bat the dir will still be from where the bat last ran. The only way to change that is to add a dir you want it to open to be default with the Task parameters, like this:

Given the op considers the issues he was having resolved, this issue can probably be closed.. @Maximus5 That'll be because for what ever reason, it wasn't checking for updates. Not sure why, that's not something I'd turn off unless there was an issue with an update.

With this I'd assume that the default settings are used on the very first run after an update/install, which would seem to indicate the changes above are still the correct way to override the defaults to get the desired results (a clean console when you start a new one). upgrading the build.
standard msys2 install:
1. install msys2
2. apply rolling updates with: pacman -Syu
3. terminate the process according to installation instructions (do not
exit cleanly, terminate the process without executing a clean shutdown)
4. restart msys2
5. repeat step 2 until all rolling updates applied
add msys2 packages:
1. pacman -S conemu

I had a similar problem, using "C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe" /C "C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu\wsl\conemu-cyg-64.exe" "/cygdrive/c/Program Files/ConEmu/ConEmu/wsl/wslbridge.exe" caused the system to claim it could not run C:\Program. Removing the wsl from wsl\conemu-cyg-64.exe and copying wsl\cygwin1.dll to C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu fixed the isse. Actually wsl\conemu-cyg-64.exe does not exist, but whatever is called instead causes the error.... Thanks @Maximus5, I didn't notice the new entry after updating earlier.... 170807 fixes this partly. When I run the automatically generated {Bash::bash}
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt

, the only weird thing is an AltGr-Deadkey-Tilde which my (customized) layout has (though IIRC the original Swiss-German layout also has this). Instead of the usual ~ followed by space, I now have to enter ~ twice. That's acceptable (and how often do I need to type a ñ on WSL?) though confusing.
What still doesn't work though is searching through history via arrow keys, which ~/.inputrc's
## arrow up
"\e[A":history-search-backward
## arrow down
"\e[B":history-search-forward

should achieve. But maybe that's a problem with some other config files...
If I instead use the Task
"C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu\conemu-cyg-64.exe" "/cygdrive/c/Program Files/ConEmu/ConEmu/wsl/wslbridge.exe"

(I thing the major difference is the lack of the :p console switch), the Deadkey-Tilde works fine, but the arrow keys don't.. For proper arrow function, p4 apparently must be inactive, i.e. instead of -cur_console:p I think -cur_console:p1 is the proper setting. Though at the moment I don't see any difference from omitting it. But apparently now the 256 colors don't work anymore despite the wslbridge task.
And the tilde-deadkey still behaves wrong, and more confusingly this seems to depend on whether I used wslbridge or pure bash.exe first after a reboot... Just a note, I checked: The deadkey-tilde is also present in the native DE-CH keyboard layout, so anyone in Switzerland might encounter the same problem. Another AltGr-Deadkey is ´, which also behaves weird. Sometimes it just works, sometimes it seems to cause a TAB to be passed, sometimes nothing happens. But maybe I should open a new issue for AltGr-Deadkeys, since the originally posted bug is fixed.... @techexo Thanks for reminding me to add that reboot information to #1224, so you also agree that depends on which task you started first after booting?.

I'm looking over all the settings and cannot find where to switch to the old behavior.

As for Far Manager, Ctrl+Shift+\<digit> does not work for me (and does not work by default), and also there I cannot find any option to change that.. Thank you for your help! Suddenly ConEmu started being very useful to me :)
It's not that obvious though. The documentation mentions that the 'host key' is configurable, but does not explain how to proceed exactly and the option named 'host key' is nowhere to be found. Other than that, I've noticed that after changing the key the option mentioned by me changed its name ('LCtrl' has been replaced by 'Win' in my case). This is kind of surprising, and seeing the option like 'LCtrl+Numbers - activate console' suggested that the only thing to do is to switch it on/off - that's why I was sure that the keys combination is not configurable.
For example of how confusing all of this is, one excerpt from the docs:
'Note, Win is default ‘Host key’, keys combination is configurable.'
and the word 'configurable' is a link that leads to... some screenshot of 'Main->Tab bar' configuration menu, which does not contain any option to configure this... FAQ didn't help much either.
So... maybe it is worth explaining this in the docs. There is a multitude of options. To you - the author of this (great!) software - these may be obvious. Not so for someone just getting accustomed to it.. Yes, that was the first place where I went. The addition of the n flag in %windir%\system32\bash.exe -cur_console:npm:/mnt works for the Bash::bash (Windows Linux Subsystem) shell.
The addition of the n flag in set CHERE_INVOKING=1 & set "PATH=%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\usr\bin;%PATH%" & "%ConEmuBaseDir%\conemu-msys2-64.exe" -new_console:np %ConEmuDrive%\msys64\usr\bin\bash.exe --login -i -new_console:C:"%ConEmuDrive%\msys64\msys2.ico" works for MSYS2.
Could these become default in the next conemu release?. Hmm, looks like conemu->Settings->Startup->Specified named task was the setting I was looking for.. >  It works perfectly.

PenelopeFudd:
I found the problem; I had specified the PuTTY command line as 'user@hostname', when I should have done "-load mysession".  
As a result, the settings were PuTTY's defaults, not my saved settings, which explained why double-clicking didn't highlight correctly.. Incidentally, "RTFM" contains a swear word and generally indicates disrespect.  Maybe use longer pre-canned responses to avoid unnecessary hard feelings in new users?
If the manual weren't so big, or if it were a question-and-answer troubleshooting guide, or if it had this exact problem listed, then RTFM would have worked before this issue was created.
I really like the extensive use of tooltips in the program; good job.. Perhaps replace "RTFM" with "It looks like this problem might be caused by a misunderstanding of how ConEmu works; this page may help: "+$link.
That sentence is generic enough that it could be used with pretty much any newbie question.
In this case, I had thought that ConEmu was taking control of the text selection process because PuTTY was acting differently when run from ConEmu, and thus the ChildGui page did not apply.  After a more-careful reading of that page, it became clear that yes, it always applies to PuTTY.
After reading that, changing the settings in PuTTY fixed highlighting; but then restarting ConEmu broke the highlighting again.  The next hypothesis was that ConEmu was preventing PuTTY from loading or maybe saving its settings.  While typing that here, I realized that the PuTTY command line was not loading my settings because it only had user@hostname on the command line, not '-load xyz'.
In conclusion, troubleshooting is a journey from hypothesis to hypothesis, and documenting possible paths will shorten the trip.  If you can dump your expertise into a question-and-answer format (on the wiki?), and get people to go to it first, you'll not have to do as much hand-holding.
Thanks!.

xianghongai:
fix:
git bash command line: git config --global core.autocrlf true
or
windows + r: %userprofile%，edit .gitconfig file:
[user]
    email = Your@Email.com
    name = YourName
[core]
    quotepath = false
    safecrlf = false.

sgabenov:
place a prompt.lua file to cmder\config folder
```
function my_prompt_filter()
    cwd = clink.get_cwd()
    prompt = "\x1b[1;32;40m{cwd}{git}{hg} $> "
    new_value = string.gsub(prompt, "{cwd}", cwd)
    clink.prompt.value = string.gsub(new_value, "{lamb}", "λ")
end
clink.prompt.register_filter(my_prompt_filter, 1)
```.

refack:
@Maximus5 IMHO the edge case here is that in node we can set an empty string env var:
js
process.env.foobar='';
attached is a minimally reproducing script and a Procmon PML trace
conemu-1209.zip
The env var foobar get converted from an empty string to a NULL with the first spawn
In the second spawn a bug on node's side converts the js undefined value to its string representation
. AFAICT on both sides
ComEmu converts empty strings to null
node convert null to undefined. Confirmed was broken and now fixed here as well. Thanks all.

patrickcarlohickman:
I found that you can change the terminal mode on the current window using the status bar. Is there a shortcut available to be able to change/toggle the terminal mode? I did not see one in the shortcut list.. I'm looking for an easy way to change the mode after the console is already started.
So, for example, I use the cmd task (cmd /k "%ConEmuDir%\..\init.bat"  -new_console:d:%USERPROFILE%). Terminal mode is Windows and the arrow keys work perfectly.
Inside this shell, I run docker-compose exec workspace bash to enter bash inside my workspace container. Now, the arrow keys do not work. At this point, I need to change the terminal mode to xterm for the arrows to work correctly.
When I exit the bash session in my docker container, I need to change the terminal mode back to Windows since I'm back in the plain cmd shell.
So, I was just hoping there was a shortcut I could use to switch the terminal mode without having to use the mouse and the status bar. Ideally I'd love to be able to hook into some type of event that fires for every command typed in the shell, but I don't think that exists..

connerbw:
I'm running ConEmu 171205 [64] Alpha. I'm using this script provided by GitHub. It's in my .bash_profile file.
```
env=~/.ssh/agent.env
agent_load_env () { test -f "$env" && . "$env" >| /dev/null ; }
agent_start () {
    (umask 077; ssh-agent >| "$env")
    . "$env" >| /dev/null ; }
agent_load_env
agent_run_state: 0=agent running w/ key; 1=agent w/o key; 2= agent not running
agent_run_state=$(ssh-add -l >| /dev/null 2>&1; echo $?)
if [ ! "$SSH_AUTH_SOCK" ] || [ $agent_run_state = 2 ]; then
    agent_start
    ssh-add
elif [ "$SSH_AUTH_SOCK" ] && [ $agent_run_state = 1 ]; then
    ssh-add
fi
unset env
```

lordjeb:
I would like to fix this bug and submit a PR. What I have found is that the call to KERNEL32!GetConsoleKeyboardLayoutNameW results in a call to KERNEL32!ConsoleCallServer which returns 0x80004001, which is a status not implemented error code. But then the function uses RtlNtStatusToDosError to try to convert error code to a DOS/Win32 code. There is not a mapping for that, so it returns ERROR_MR_MID_NOT_FOUND to ConEmu. (And prints some additional error output in a kernel debugger that is not mentioned in this issue currently.)
So ConEmu could key off that return code and never call the API again after it hits that. There are a handful of places where this function gets dynamically loaded and called, but the one that calls over and over is in IsKeyboardLayoutChanged in ConsoleMain.cpp.
So should I...
(a) Change only the function IsKeyboardLayoutChanged, have it recognize the error code, set a static variable to not make the call any more.
(b) Make a wrapper function for GetConsoleKeyboardLayoutName that can make it so none of the other places get called multiply as well. Change all the other locations to call this wrapper.
(c) Other?.

Is there some nasty coding required to achieve this?

By the way, why do you run tabs via -reuse switch?  

This is the problem statement:
What options do I have to load an entire set of tabs (where each tab contains a shell) in the background in a conemu window?
The python script iterates a folder containing .sh files, and executes them one by one with the command above. The first file is executed without the "-reuse" switch, so as to create a new instance. Subsequent files are loaded with the -reuse switch so as to reuse said instance.

How do you run python scripts?

Since it turned out that there was a lot of difference between the actual font width used and the Unicode East Asian Width property, I decided to change the method and reference the glyph metrics of the actual font.
As a result, I was able to generate Unicode ranges that fits in 1024 characters.
Example
The following is an example of a combination of a specific font and a character range for each language.
For U+2500-257F (Box Drawing), full-width characters on the alternative font side are not included so that they do not shift with ncurses, pstree or the like.
For U+10000 or higher, decide without reference to metrics, CJK Extension B - F and Variation Selectors Supplement etc are converted into surrogate pair and included.

Последовательно запускаю из комстроки команду "определить нажатое кнопкосочетание" — lua:far.Message(mf.key(mf.waitkey(0,1)),"Searching...","") и затем нажимаю соответствующие кнопкосочетания с клавишей Esc. И в результате они либо определяются в соответствии с нажатиями, либо вызывают системные команды:
CtrlEsc — вызов меню Пуск;
AltEsc — переключиться в другое окно;
ShiftEsc √
CtrlAltEsc √
CtrlShiftEsc — диспетчер задач;
AltShiftEsc — текущая папка открывается в проводнике;
CtrlAltShiftEsc √
Голый Far после запуска из комстроки команды определения нажатых кнопок из нажатий на вышеперечисленные кнопкосочетания реагирует только на ShiftEsc и правильно его определяет. В остальных же случаях либо следует вызов тех же системных команд, либо (в случаях нажатия CtrlAltEsc и CtrlAltShiftEsc) реакция вовсе отсутствует. 
После установки в Far скрипта XKeys голый Far в ответ на команду определить нажаты клавиши правильно определяет каждое из вышеперечисленных кнопкосочетаний, и системные команды при этом не вызываются. 
В загруженном же из-под ConEmu Far`е с установленным скриптом XKeys после ввода в комстроку команды определения клавиш следуют усечённые ответы, как это показано в самом первом посте…

А ведь система и другие программы перехватывают у Farа и куда более применимые шорткаты. Например, весьма полезная программа SystemExplorer перехватывает CtrlAltIns. Но в её случае это хотя бы можно предотвратить в настройках самой программы, с частичной потерей её функциональности. А вот Панель управления HD-графикой Intel перехватывает целую группу шорткатов: 
CtrlAltF6 — открыть Панель клавиш быстрого вызова.
CtrlAltF1 — открыть Панель дисплея.
CtrlAltF11 — открыть Панель масштабирования.
CtrlAltF12 — открыть Панель HD-графикой Intel©.
CtrlAlt↑(вверх) — поворот экрана на 0 градусов.
CtrlAlt←(влево) — поворот экрана на 90 градусов.
CtrlAlt↓(вниз) — поворот экрана на 180 градусов.
CtrlAlt→(вправо) — поворот экрана на 270 градусов.
В настойках панели их можно выключить, установив галочку на опции √ Выключить. С потерей соответствующей функциональности. Однако комбинация CtrlAltF8 включает их вновь. mhofman:
FYI, this might be coming natively: rprichard/wslbridge#18. Update to the Windows 10 Fall Creator Update (1709).. Until this is supported natively by wslbridge, I've managed to get .profile to execute, i.e. get an interactive login shell by executing the connector this way:
%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-msys2-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt - -t -- /bin/bash -i -l
The -t is to get wslbridge to open a pty since we're executing a command.
Of course the -i -l is to get Bash's interactive login shell.
Anything after the first - is the args passed to wslbridge.exe.
Anything after the -- is the command executed by wslbridge-backend.. Correct, but I didn't see a new connector release with that code change.
Also, still useful information for anyone who wants to run a different shell, since wslbridge doesn't respect the user's default shell.
Also, since the connector now explicitly sets the command to execute, when wslbridge does get around to natively support login shell or user's default shell, this change will have to be undone.. I'm running the preview channel.. Wondering what is the "better" way to use WSL: through wslbridge or simply invoking wsl.exe -new_console:pm:/mnt [{guid}] which seems to work out of the box? (And I guess the -new_console:p won't be needed after #1291 ?)
With wsl.exe, you get true login shell on the distribution of your choice, but broken console (colors, and possibly other things like resizing).
With the bridge you currently can't get a proper login shell, a non bash shell, nor selectable distribution.. It does support it in the 0.24 version of wslbridge
After some some trial and error, I did finally figure it out. The trick was to add a - after the --wsl flag.
For anyone searching, I managed to get a Login shell through wslbridge, using a specific distribution.
Here is the full command line I used:
%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-msys2-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt - -t --distro-guid {0302fe33-e328-413d-8520-077ab52d55ad} -- /bin/bash -i -l. Anything after the first - is the args passed to wslbridge.exe. I had to include this, without it, the arguments were ingested by the connector itself, with it complaining of unknown args.
The -t is to get wslbridge to open a pty since we're executing a command.
Anything after the -- is the command executed by wslbridge-backend..

  -l, --log <dir>  write console IN and OUT to files in `dir` folder

      --debug      wait for debugger for 60 seconds
      --environ    print environment on startup
      --isatty     do isatty checks and print pts names
      --keys       read conin and print bare input
      --shlvl      forces `set SHLVL=1` to avoid terminal reset on exit
      --verbose    additional information during startup
      --version    print version of this tool
      --wsl        run wslbridge to start Bash on Ubuntu on Windows 10

Neutrino-Sunset:
Yes. I've adjusted the task for {Shells::cmd} to
cmd.exe /k "%ConEmuBaseDir%\CmdInit.cmd -git"
...and that switch in turn causes CmdInit.cmd to execute
GitShowBranch /i
But this doesn't actually cause any git prompt to appear. After navigating to a git repo the prompt remains unchanged. You have to manually enter 'GitShowBranch' on the command line to cause the prompt to appear.
If you then make a change in that repo, add a file or edit something, the prompt still doesn't update automatically, you have to enter GitShowBranch again to update it. You have to run GitShowBranch everytime you do anything that modifies the repo for the git prompt to be updated. Which isn't very useful.
Looking through GitShowBranch it's mostly simple stuff. When GitShowBranch is called with /i the prompt is modified to include $E]9;8;"gitbranch" which I believe causes ConEmu to insert the value of the 'gitbranch' environment variable into the prompt.
When GitShowBranch is subsequently called without /i it calls 'git status' and creates a value for 'gitbranch' based on the number of file changes. But there is nothing obvious in the script that would cause this to happen automatically.
Although in the statement to set the prompt there is one thing I don't understand which is the $E]9;7;"cmd -cur_console:R /c%~nx0" 
Of this the documentation says "R - force start hooks server in the parent process". But I already have "Inject ConEmuHk" checked in the ConEmu settings and have no idea why this would be being called from inside the statement that sets the prompt. 
So at the moment even after adding the /git switch to the task startup the prompt is only ever updated when you manually call GitShowBranch on the commandline, and I'm looking for a way to make that happen automatically whenever I enter any command.
. I'll start by saying I've got it working. What I had done was make a copy of CmdInit.cmd called MyCmdInit.cmd, and a copy of GitShowBranch.cmd called MyGitShowBranch.cmd and in MyCmdInit.cmd I'd replaced the call to "GitShowBranch /i" with "MyGitShowBranch.cmd /i". What I wanted to do was modify GitShowBranch to enhance the prompt to indicate upstream changes and stuff.
But without modifying a single line in MyGitShowBranch that doesn't work. I don't see why. Is ConEmu's use of GitShowBranch hardcoded so renaming it breaks the updating? If so, not a problem, I'll just make a backup and modify the original.

. Adding 'cmd -cur_console:R /cMyGitShowBranch.cmd' to the list of allowable commands enabled me to get a copy of GitShowBranch.cmd working.
The build I have is published as the latest stable build, I only downloaded it on Friday, but I'll update to preview as you recommend.
Thanks for the help..

. So the following fixed pasting for me:


Installing fresh: ConEmu (b171109x64)
Setting task as described above:
1   {Bash:bash}
Commands:
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --log --wsl -cur_console:pnm:/mnt -t bash -l

This resulted WSL starting correctly ,and <Ctrl-V> pasting without any further issue.
This was tested in few different environments:
 Users: root, main user
 Shell: bash, zsh (launched inside terminal, e.g.via .bashrc)
Edit: I also tried to get --log switch to work and output log, but even when running As Administrator, no log seems to appear anywhere in C:\Prog...\ConEmu directory tree.. I believe using the bash.exe directly does not use the connector.
For example, you say you have for your task {Bash::bash}:
%windir%\system32\bash.exe -cur_console:pm:/mnt --login -i -new_console
I, personally, replaced everything in my {Bash::bash} task with the following:
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --log --wsl -cur_console:pnm:/mnt -t bash -l
I believe this does use the connector and is how I'm now using the bash terminal on windows.
Specifically, I'm no longer connecting directly to the bash.exe.
If there is no reason to not use the connector, I would say just replace your bash task with the custom task commands and run that way instead of the default \bash.exe way.. @rymanske check if you experience same lag in regular, non-ConEmu bash.exe as @ltomes mentions.

philonor:
Follow up:
- ConEmu starts automatically on my machine using a bash script
start "" "C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu64.exe" -dir %MP%
- The script is run on startup using Windows Task Scheduler
- Although the loaded account is a non-admin account, the Windows Task Scheduler option Run with highest privileges seems to force admin-privileges
- This resulted in ConEmu always spawning terminals with admin priviliges (even when selecting a non-admin console) 
- In the ConEmu "Create new console" window,  Run as administrator was always checked and greyed out

- Deactivating the Run with highest privileges option in Windows Task Scheduler fixed my problem

. It's an interactive task we're talking about, difficult to automate, 
but let's give it a try:


Open cmd.exe in ConEmu, and go to "Settings | Keys & Macros" and uncheck both confirmations when pasting (to avoid any "interactivity" delays).


Create time-paste.cmd script in cwd with this content
   (adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/a/35524720/548792):


```bat
   @echo off
:start
   REM Start time storage
   @echo Paste something song, then press [Enter], [Ctrl+Z]
   echo
set ST=%time%
Rem read STDIN
   TYPE CON  
set ENTIME=%time% 
:end
   REM Start Time Definition
   for /f "tokens=1-3 delims=:" %%a in ("%ST%") do set /a h1=%%a & set /a m1=%%b & set /a s1=%%c
REM End Time Definition
   for /f "tokens=1-3 delims=:" %%a in ("%ENTIME%") do set /a h2=%%a & set /a m2=%%b & set /a s2=%%c
REM Difference
   set /a h3=%h2%-%h1% & set /a m3=%m2%-%m1% & set /a s3=%s2%-%s1%
REM Time Adjustment
   if %h3% LSS 0 set /a h3=%h3%+24
   if %m3% LSS 0 set /a m3=%m3%+60 & set /a h3=%h3%-1
   if %s3% LSS 0 set /a s3=%s3%+60 & set /a m3=%m3%-1
echo Start    :    %ST%
   echo End      :    %time%
   echo Total    :    %h3%:%m3%:%s3%
   ```


Copy a long "reference" file in your clipboard (long enough to diminish the ratio of any "interactivity" delays), e.g. with curl in the PATH, enter:
curl -vs 2>&1 https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/master/src/ConEmu.vcxproj | clip


Finally execute the command below, and WITHOUT WASTING ANY TIME paste the clipboard and close immediately stream:
time-paste
[Shift+Insert]
[Enter]
[Ctrl+Z]

instead of scp-ing stuff around.. But it's probably off-topic here, no?. Any updates on that?.

Here is my use case: vim. I often run vim through ConEmu, and want to paste a large snippet. I am ignorant to what actually happens when I paste into a terminal, but I have always been confused that I have to wait for text to slowly appear line by line in vim in ConEmu while in other terminal emulators (mintty on Windows, xfce4-terminal on Linux) it is near-instant.
As an example, copying all the text from this page (ctrl+a), roughly 10734 characters and 250 lines, then pasting into vim 8.0.237:

- cmd.exe: 2 seconds
- mintty: 0.5 seconds
Rough, non-scientific counting based on the time I click paste (or "Ok to prompt in ConEmu") to the time the terminal window stops scrolling.

mintty:
According to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms645612(v=vs.85).aspx
it's "sent when the cursor is in an inactive window and the user presses a mouse button."
So maybe Windows sends it implicitly because ConEmu has pulled the focus to itself?
I've traced mintty within ConEmu and in fact it is getting this message on every mouse click.. The "Focus in child windows" setting does not make a difference. The child application is getting sent a WM_MOUSEACTIVATE message every time a mouse button is clicked. Please reopen this bug.. Retested with ConEmu 180309 on Windows 10 build 17115.
Mintty gets a WM_MOUSEACTIVATE delivered on each mouse click, which is a bug; unaffected by the "Focus in child windows" setting.
However, mintty has a workaround for this for the next release.. Mintty cannot "fix" it because it's a ConEmu bug (or maybe a Windows bug).
But mintty 2.8.5 will have a workaround.. Released mintty 2.8.5 with a workaround.. See #1368; the child application is getting sent a WM_MOUSEACTIVATE message every time a mouse button is clicked, independently of the "Focus in child windows" setting.. Mintty 2.8.5 has a workaround, at the cost of one of its features; this doesn't mean that the conemu issue is fixed.. You may not be sending it, but mintty receives it,
see https://github.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/issues/1368#issuecomment-354438028.
There are lots of occurrences of "Activate" and "SetFocus" in the conemu sources (too many for a quick check), what e.g. about ConEmu/TaskBarGhost.cpp: gpConEmu->Activate(mp_VCon) ?.

. might be a font issue. I encountered a similar problem, in which case a special unicode character is missing in the font I set in conemu. keep in mind some programs will simple use system's fallback font for missing glyphs. so even if you use the same font for conemu and other programs (e.g. browser or notepad), the behavior might be different.
check your font to find out whether it misses the glyphs you need. or try fonts with better unicode support like dejavu family.
. as I said, programs like notepad have a fallback mechanism for missing glyphs in fonts. actually most programs will use a fallback font provided by the operating system if you use standard Windows widgets (or as also called controls).
but if a program is drawing glyphs on its own, like conemu or games, the operating system will not help you choose a fallback font when some glyphs are missing.
so, notepad will always display the character, as long there is a font installed in your system that supports that specific character. encoding is another orthognal issue, though.
the "▣" character you metioned renders fine on my machine in conemu, so I am faily certain it's a font issue. and I'm kind of certain that lucida is very old and doesn't have good unicode support.
simple solution: install the dejavu font family, which has a very good reputation regarding unicode support, and then change your conemu settings. if you need CJK fonts (like me), "source han sans" is a good choice
if you are curious enough, you may try to examine the problematic font file using font editing tools, like fontforge.
or, you can also try the font in programs which are rendering fonts themselves (don't use Windows programs like notepad). as far as I know, on windows, emacs and gvim are such programs. but there are caveats:
  * gvim only support monospaced fonts
  * emacs has its own fonts fallback mechanism (which is different from the operating system), but you can always use the describe-char command. just FYI, the font I'am using is https://github.com/be5invis/Sarasa-Gothic
its a source han sans derivation,

And then, ConEmu terminates all the child processes, including those that are completely unrelated to the batch operation currently running. This is not what was expected.. @Maximus5 

ConEmu does not terminate anything by Ctrl+C.
GUI applications are not attached into ConEmu console automatically, unless they do that themselves.
Ctrl+C is a feature of OS, sort of signals in Unix. It's absolutely on your applications what they do when signal is received. And of course, the signal comes only into applications attached to that console.

Should I update logs?. Updated gist with ANSI logs.. No it's not Microsoft problem. ConEmu doesn't sets registry keys properly. I can demonstrate.
This is what ConEmu creates in registry:
```
Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT*\shell\ConEmu &Here]
"Icon"="C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu64.exe,0"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT*\shell\ConEmu &Here\command]
@="\"C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu64.exe\" -here -run {powershell} -cur_console:n"
This is how it _should_ be:
Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT*\shell\ConEmu &Here]
"Icon"="C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu64.exe,0"
@="ConEmu &Here"
[HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT*\shell\ConEmu &Here\command]
@="\"C:\Program Files\ConEmu\ConEmu64.exe\" -here -run {powershell} -cur_console:n"
``
Notice the difference in default key@="ConEmu &Here". ConEmu doesn't set it.. The only problem on Microsoft side is Windows displaying wrong marker where it shouldn't.

function ANSI () {
    $ESC = [char]27
$ST = "$ESC\"

$black   = "$ESC[30m"

$green   = "$ESC[32m"

$magenta = "$ESC[35m"

function IsConEmu () {
    $exitcode = 0;
    try {
        & ConEmuC.exe --% /IsConEmu
        $exitcode = $LASTEXITCODE
    }
    catch [System.Management.Automation.CommandNotFoundException] {
        $exitcode = 2;
    }
$IsConEmu = $exitcode -eq 1

return $IsConEmu

}
function prompt () {
if (IsConEmu) {
    . ANSI

    $prompt = `
        "${Title}PS $PWD${ST}" + `
        "${CWD}$PWD${ST}" + `
        "${reset}" + `
        "${green}$env:USERNAME@$env:COMPUTERNAME ${yellow}$PWD`n" + `
        "${reset}`$ "
} else {
    $prompt = `
        "PS $PWD`n" + `
        '$ '
}

return $prompt

}
```

. C# console application on Debug/Any CPU.. devenv.exe-26500.log was created during the debug attempt. Here's of a successful run without debug, then an attempt at debug. There is extra stuff at the beginning, looks like it grabbed the execution of grunt too.
devenv.exe-33172.log. So, the project was being built with Any CPU, but it had the "prefer 32-bit" option enabled. Removing this (or building for x64 directly) launches the console application just fine, however, it is not being captured by ConEmu.
So in short, launching 32-bit returns "The request is not supported", x64 is fine, but not being captured by ConEmu.. @Maximus5, looks like 653a651f1d9d5c257c56e876799a88c3ce35459d did the trick. Running in preview, at v18.04.15 at the moment, and debugged my solution when it popped up in ConEmu.

may this helpls a little to find the reason. BTW may some people helps this workaround for subcase openend from freeCommander. written in AHK (updated at: 14.05.2018 14:19)
IfWinActive,ahk_class FreeCommanderXE
IfWinActive,ahk_class FreeCommanderXE.SingleInst.1
^d::
  WinGetActiveTitle , at
  atWithoutClass := Rtrim( RegExReplace(at, "- FreeCommander.*",""))
  if(!atWithoutClass)
    return
  Suspend,on
  Send,^d ; %  at
  loop,9
  {
    sleep,50
    WinWaitActive,ahk_class VirtualConsoleClass,,1
    ifwinNotactive,ahk_class VirtualConsoleClass
    WinActivate,ahk_class VirtualConsoleClass
    WinSetTitle, , , % atWithoutClass
    WinWaitActive,% atWithoutClass " ahk_class VirtualConsoleClass",,1
    ifwinactive, % atWithoutClass " ahk_class VirtualConsoleClass"
      continue
  }
  Suspend,off
return

git-cmd.exe --no-cd --command=usr/bin/bash.exe -l -i -new_console:p

skipmeister123:
Respectfully, I strongly disagree.  While this behavior holds true for something such as a text editor, I believe this is the incorrect way to approach a terminal emulator.
I would posit these two thoughts:
1) If I set my terminal to 80x25, then increase the text size but the window doesn't change size, how many columns do I have?
2) Change the font size on cmd.exe, and watch what happens to the window size..
jdputsch:
Quite respectfully, I must fully agree with skipmeister123. While ConEmu may be a UI application, it is a TERMINAL application and terminal windows have, until resized, a given number of rows and a given number of columns where the number of columns does not change based on font-size. For example 80x25.
If I change the font size, then I would expect the size of the window to change to to maintain a fixed number of rows and columns.
This is not the same as the existing fixed console size in terms of cells option. I should be able to resize my console, which will change the number of cells. But when I scale the fonts, the number of cells should not change -- this means the size of the window should change.
As pointed out by skipmeister123: cmd.exe behaves exactly in the manner he and I are asking for.
.

It only happens when running WSL directly through ConEmu.. Well, up until 1803 there was no problem with it. All I/O worked just fine. The default {bash} task wouldn't do for me because, well, I don't use bash. I use ZSH and I'm guessing most of us who've replaced the default task with a direct call to WSL did it for that reason. bash.exe loads just that: bash. wsl.exe loads the way you'd expect a terminal emulator to load on any UNIX system, namely that it loads whatever shell you've set for your user account.
By clicking through the docs a bit I've now figured out that we can actually use ZSH through the bridge as well, by use of the -t flag on the CygWin/MSYS connector.
You may want to update the FAQ for Bash on Windows by mentioning that one can control which shell is loaded through that flag, because it's not exactly clear. You have to go into the connector docs to find that out. That should help with the repeated queries about this.. Looks like the next version of wslbridge will do this correctly and not force bash by default. At which point I'd suggest your connector to also no longer default to -t bash.. Be that as it may, for the past 6-7 months or so  (that's when I switched back to Windows from my Mac) I've been using ConEmu with it set up to launch wsl.exe (so not bash.exe) directly and I haven't experienced any lost characters in pastes or anything. I'm sure some things wouldn't have worked that I simply haven't tried, but pasting wasn't one of them. The only "issue" I had with pasting was that newlines would be duplicated, but that's hardly a problem.
Perhaps something changed shortly after the mentioned issue's date and I stepped in at just the right time? I don't know what else would explain it.
At any rate, you're right, the default task does let me paste as normal now, so for the time being I'll run it with -t zsh -l. With version 0.2.5 of wslbridge it'll get rid of the bash default though and I think you should then follow their lead and either change the default bash task to leave it up to WSL or perhaps add a new default task {wsl}?
But that's food for another day (and GH PR/issue) when 0.2.5 is out :P
And just for reference for everyone else: this is how I'm starting my shell now, which is with zsh rather than bash:
set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -t zsh -l
It's ever so slightly modified from the default, barely any difference..

jpwilksch:
I agree it takes some getting used to. However, in recent times I've seen a number of default Linux prompts also using the two-line format.
If you'd like the cmd prompt without a newline:

Edit %ConEmuBaseDir%\CmdInit.cmd
Remove the leading "$_" (newline/carriage return) from ConEmuPrompt2 on the two lines it is set

eg. Change
set ConEmuPrompt2=$_$E[90m$G
to
set ConEmuPrompt2=$E[90m$G
Additionally, you can replace ">" with "$" by substituting $$ for $G on the same lines.
Note this file will be overwritten when you update ConEmu, so you should probably copy it to a new file in the same directory and make the updates there. You'll also need to update your {cmd} Tasks to reference the new file.

const wchar_t* posixSpec = bAutoQuote ? L"$" : L" ()$!";. Escaping ! in quoted string doesn't work in mingw/bash
```
Double quoted, escaped with \
$ cd "c:\folder with space\spaces and bang !! bang"
bash: cd: c:\folder with space\spaces and bang !! bang: No such file or directory
Single quoted, escaped with \

bash: cd: c:\folder with space\spaces and bang !! bang: No such file or directory
Double quoted, unescaped
$ cd "c:\folder with space\spaces and bang !! bang"

Single quoted, unescaped

OK
Unquoted, -escapd

OK, but looks ugly compared to the single quoted, unescaped
Double quoted + single quoted !

OK

Sorry about that. The hotkey binding itself isn't really important to me as the functionality. I don't believe there is a way to enter into a mode where I can get a vi-style cursor to navigate the buffer and highlight/copy text.. Sorry again.
Feature:
A mode, which can be activated via a hotkey that:

Freezes the buffer
Changes the text cursor's behavior so that using directional keys moves the cursor to different parts of the buffer
Using shift and a directional key will select parts of the buffer
Selected buffer can be copied via normal means, such as the user's preferred hotkey or right clicking the text and selecting "copy"

This is perhaps an extension of the functionality of Pause and Alternative Buffer because it adds the ability of navigating the buffer with a cursor..

. > it requires a single undocumented but exported function
If it's not documented, don't take a dependency on it. We no make guarantee that an implementation detail will continue to work in the future.
Furthermore, conhost.exe is the host for all conpty sessions. If anyone's using the conpty API's, then hooking all conhost.exe launches would mean that a ConEmu would get launched even for conpty sessions, which is probably NOT what you want to have happen. 
I can share that setting a default terminal application is a pain point that we're aware of and investigating a official, supported solution. .

ConEmu doesn't come with any SSH at all. If Cmder includes SSH then they are the ones to bind SSH to whatever terminal they use. It's like blaming Hunts when McDonald's put the ketchup in Coke.
Removing system SSH would be more absurd for ConEmu (though it may make sense for Cmder).
In contrast, "making ConEmu work with OpenSSH" (or even "making OpenSSH-Win32 work with ConEmu") is what this issue targets.. Sorry for late reply. Well, gee, see, I was in a place where I couldn't access my development system and look up the version # I'd installed this morning, so, in a misguided attempt to provide you some information as quickly as I could I referenced the "stable" release, thinking that the author -- and presumed releaser -- of the software would know what version that meant. My apologies for assuming a level of knowledge on your part which apparently does not exist.
The version # I have -- which I saw billed as "stable" -- is 161206. The problem exists with that build.
In the interest of getting past the knee-jerk attempt to ignore user feedback, I just now downloaded and installed the "latest" version -- 180626, in case you don't have your release log handy -- and installed that.
You may be pleased to learn that the issue I was writing about -- in a two year old release -- is still present in the brand spanking new latest and greatest version. Setting ConEmu to force taking over consoles prevents Visual Studio 2017 from attaching to the Azure Function host process and debugging it. Turning off that option, and having VS 2017 revert to using plain old console windows allows debugging to proceed normally.
I'd call that pretty definitive evidence there's still a problem in ConEmu. Your mileage, no doubt, will be different.
Have a nice day!

DRempfer:
Replying to my own question: 
I accidentally found that simply redefining the screen-clear command like so:
alias cls='clear; echo -ne "\e[32766H\e[$((LINES - 1))A"'
and then just issuing a cls at the end of my .bashrc will make 24-bit color work fine with no other changes to ConEmu's Bash::bash task required. It turns out that 24-bit color support is kind of hacky/kludgy (e.g., if I open and close Vim, the colors shown on the screen will change), but this trick makes things work alright, kind of.. Well when you run a script to automate things on a keyboard shortcut, for example to grab a url with curl or to start a GUI command (X window or even a Windows GUI program) you generaly don't care of the output. For the rare cases when the script fails and debug is needed, there are many options. To cite a few:
- run in an existing terminal
- temporarily set an option in ConEmu so the console ALWAYS stays
- redirect stdout/stderr inside the script, to some file.

Hi  @Maximus5, 
Thank you for the extremely unexpected swift response !
It worked !
For anyone who might be confused or face the same issue.


Make sure to use the latest ConEmu build.


Open Setup Tasks, after clicking the green + dropdown on the right.


Go to startup > Tasks.


Find {Bash::bash} on the Predefined task list.


Copy and Paste this on the task parameter box :


/dir %CD% /icon "%USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\lxss\bash.ico"

Copy and Paste this in the big white box at the bottom :

set "PATH=%ConEmuBaseDirShort%\wsl;%PATH%" & %ConEmuBaseDirShort%\conemu-cyg-64.exe --wsl -cur_console:pm:/mnt
Лучший пожелания !.

EDIT: I'm an idiot...somehow skipped over the fact that you're using PowerShell and no VIM (aka everything important).  It still looks like it's a screen write/buffer issue though.  I tried recreating it in ConEmu 180626 running same platform/plugins and couldn't reproduce it.
When I was trying to set up a PS env in Cmder though, I came across a lot of issues.  Cmder utilizes ConEmu, but can also introduce issues like this.  If you're using the default Powershell tasks, it doesn't simply launch PowerShell as you say...it's doing a lot of other stuff too.  Take a look at the vendor\profile.ps1 file in the Cmder directory to take a look.  I ended up just bypassing it and specifying my own PS profile after running into an issue similar to this one.
I then came across another issue that resembled what I was experiencing on linux, and they provide a similar fix.  The virtual terminal sequences aren't working correctly, supposedly due to cygwin API issues.  I'd ensure you have Ansi / xterm / Inject ConEmuHK Injection enabled in ConEmu > settings > features.  There's also the option to turn on Log Console Output (*) which will show you all the ANSI sequences being written to your console.  That may shed some light on things. 
In case it helps, here's the task definition I'm using for an admin PowerShell task.  Change -new_console:a:d:%USERPROFILE% to -new_console:d:%USERPROFILE% for a regular session.
chcp 65001 & PowerShell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoLogo -NoExit -NoProfile -Command "Invoke-Expression '%USERPROFILE%\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Microsoft.Powershell_profile.ps1'" -new_console:a:d:%USERPROFILE%
I also had issues with the first powerline for powershell repo I found, and ended up switching to oh-my-posh (which just worked).  I used this guide.
If it's an ANSI issue...There are also some examples for testing ANSI support on this ConEmu page, as well as a PS script in vendor\conemu-maximus5\ConEmu\Addons\AnsiColors24bit.ps1 that should output a color gradient.  In Bash, I had to add a script into my boot sequence that cats Ansi escape codes to initialize TrueColor correctly.  I used [32766H which resets ANSI support.  Here's the powershell equivalent that's in the ConEmu Addons/AnsiColors24bit.ps1 PS script:
```powershell
Clean console contents (this will clean TrueColor attributes)
Write-Host (([char]27)+"[32766S")
Apply default powershell console attributes
cls
```

. @JawnZ no issues with VIM in a tmux session when I tested it.  I tested with powerline for tmux enabled and disabled with no issues.  Whether or not powerline is being used shouldn't matter as far as I can tell since it's also susceptible to the same issue of being supplied incorrect ANSI sequences. . I'd first run :set term (to show you current term type) and :set termcap (to see if t_SI and t_EI are actually set) in VIM, from both putty and conemu.  The escape sequences below that I found match up with the second set you gave, so I'd guess that you have putty running in xterm mode, but xterm isn't enabled in ConEmu's settings.
vim
if &term =~ '^xterm\|rxvt'
    " solid underscore
    let &t_SI .= "\<Esc>[4 q"
    " solid block
    let &t_EI .= "\<Esc>[2 q"
    " 1 or 0 -> blinking block
    " 3 -> blinking underscore
    " Recent versions of xterm (282 or above) also support
    " 5 -> blinking vertical bar
    " 6 -> solid vertical bar
endif
vim
if &term =~ "xterm"
    let &t_SI = "\<Esc>[6 q"
    let &t_SR = "\<Esc>[4 q"
    let &t_EI = "\<Esc>[2 q"
endif
Source: http://vim.wikia.com/wiki/Change_cursor_shape_in_different_modes

Also relevent, from here:
```
Switching screens in an xterm       xterm-screens xterm-save-screen

(From comp.editors, by Juergen Weigert, in reply to a question)
:> Another question is that after exiting vim, the screen is left as it
:> was, i.e. the contents of the file I was viewing (editing) was left on
:> the screen. The output from my previous like "ls" were lost,
:> ie. no longer in the scrolling buffer. I know that there is a way to
:> restore the screen after exiting vim or other vi like editors,
:> I just don't know how. Helps are appreciated. Thanks.
:
:I imagine someone else can answer this.  I assume though that vim and vi do
:the same thing as each other for a given xterm setup.
They not necessarily do the same thing, as this may be a termcap vs.
terminfo problem.  You should be aware that there are two databases for
describing attributes of a particular type of terminal: termcap and
terminfo.  This can cause differences when the entries differ AND when of
the programs in question one uses terminfo and the other uses termcap
(also see |+terminfo|).
In your particular problem, you are looking for the control sequences
^[[?47h and ^[[?47l.  These switch between xterms alternate and main screen
buffer.  As a quick workaround a command sequence like
    echo -n "^[[?47h"; vim ... ; echo -n "^[[?47l"
may do what you want.  (My notation ^[ means the ESC character, further down
you'll see that the databases use \E instead).
On startup, vim echoes the value of the termcap variable ti (terminfo:
smcup) to the terminal.  When exiting, it echoes te (terminfo: rmcup).  Thus
these two variables are the correct place where the above mentioned control
sequences should go.
Compare your xterm termcap entry (found in /etc/termcap) with your xterm
terminfo entry (retrieved with "infocmp -C xterm").  Both should contain
entries similar to:
    :te=\E[2J\E[?47l\E8:ti=\E7\E[?47h:
PS: If you find any difference, someone (your sysadmin?) should better check
    the complete termcap and terminfo database for consistency.
NOTE 1: If you recompile Vim with FEAT_XTERM_SAVE defined in feature.h, the
builtin xterm will include the mentioned "te" and "ti" entries.
NOTE 2: If you want to disable the screen switching, and you don't want to
change your termcap, you can add these lines to your .vimrc:
    :set t_ti= t_te=
```.

Little offtop: starting Kitty in launcher mode from ConEmu itself (or from Task list) opens empty tab and puts kitty in tray. Starting any ssh-session actually opens virtual console inside that tab. One more offtop. Not sure if this info will be helpful but Kitty's console classname is NOT changed if session started from launcher mode:
kitty.exe -launcher -classname whatever
puts kitty in tray, but virtual consoles are not changing classname and it still says "KiTTY".
From the other hand kitty.exe -classname whatever is working as expected..

namazso:
The verifier structures have been provided in Windows 2003 R2 DDK, and the project already uses exported / exposed but undocumented features.
I didn't think of it as replacing the process hooks with this entirely, more like adding it as an additional option. I, for one, would prefer verifier auto-injection and no hooks on a single executable, than injection into vital processes like explorer and placing hooks there. For production in general, avoiding both of these would be the best, but unfortunately that is not a possibility here.. Additionally, the driver option is still there, and it requires a single undocumented but exported function, present since Windows 98. (maybe even that can be avoided too with some directory hackery, I'm not sure) Might want to consider that too in case the verifier option still sounds too risky..
